    Evolution of PI3Kγ and δ Inhibitors for Inflammatory and Autoimmune Diseases

    • Matthew W. D. Perry*
      Matthew W. D. Perry
      Respiratory, Inflammation & Autoimmunity, AstraZeneca Gothenburg, Mölndal SE-431 83, Sweden
      *E-mail: [email protected]

    Get e-Alerts

    Abstract

    Phosphoinositol 3-kinases (PI3Ks) γ and δ are key enzymes in hematopoietic cells and have been seen as high-value targets for the treatment of diseases with inflammatory and immunomodulatory components since their discovery and the identification of their roles. In this Perspective we review progress in the application of inhibitors of PI3Kγ and δ to inflammatory and immunological conditions over the past 6 years. We consider progress in the understanding of the roles of PI3Kγ and PI3Kδ in immunology and inflammation, the experience from clinical trials where inhibitors have been tested, and what has been learned about the safety of their use. The extensive medicinal chemistry efforts to discover both isoform selective and dual PI3Kγδ inhibitors are analyzed and detailed. Developments in understanding the structural chemistry of the PI3K enzymes and the factors that govern isoform selectivity are discussed. The effects observed with the known inhibitor compounds in animal models are described.

    Introduction

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    In 2012 Cushing et al.(1) published a Perspective on inhibitors of PI3Kγ and δ in inflammatory and autoimmune disease. In the past 6 years there has been a great deal of progress in both chemistry and biology in the field, as judged by the numbers of patents (Figure 1; Supporting Information) and papers that have been published.
    Between 2012 and 2018, 15 compounds have progressed into clinical trials (Figures 3–6), and one, idelalisib (1), has been launched as a treatment for lymphoma (Figure 2). We review these developments; readers interested in the basics of PI3Kγ and δ biology and early medicinal chemistry are referred to the earlier Perspective. Only where significant additional data on earlier compounds have been released do we discuss these results.

    Advances in Understanding the Biology of PI3Kγ and δ

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Since the 1990s, the importance of PI3K signaling for a diverse array of cellular functions, such as cell growth, proliferation, migration, and survival, has been recognized.(2) Early studies on murine knockouts revealed structure and function of PI3Ks and enabled their classification.(3−5) Specific roles for PI3Kγ and δ isoforms, based on expression profiles apparently restricted to immune populations, and activity downstream of G-protein-coupled receptors (GPCRs) and tyrosine kinase-associated receptors, respectively, began to emerge.(6) PI3Kγ-mediated innate immune cell influx and PI3Kδ-mediated adaptive immune activation became the basis of the first drug discovery efforts. However, studies of more sophisticated kinase-dead knock-in mouse strains, the generation of selective pharmacologic tools enabling translational studies to human cells, and first findings from initial clinical trials changed the initial picture of PI3Kγ and δ signaling.
    The expression profile for PI3Kγ has expanded to include structural populations such as cardiomyocytes, fibroblasts, and smooth muscle cells. Cardiac PI3Kγ has been shown to regulate phosphodiesterases in the sarcoplasmic reticulum, a potential protective mechanism against catecholamine-induced ventricular arrythmias.(7) Increased PI3Kγ expression in fibroblasts and basal cells has been implicated in idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis.(8) Unlike in hematopoietic cells, PI3Kγ activity in nonhematopoietic cells appears to play an important role in the development of obesity and insulin resistance as observed in knockout mice.(9) Similarly, PI3Kδ expression in the epithelium may have a role in fungal-induced endoplasmic reticulum stress, thereby contributing to corticosteroid resistance.(10) Furthermore, PI3Kδ inhibition has been shown to relax human airway smooth muscle cells, producing dilation comparable to that obtained with β adrenergic compounds, the standard in asthma treatment.(11)
    Beyond these findings the understanding of how PI3Kγ and δ isoforms interconnect within complex signaling cascades during inflammation and/or autoimmunity has increased. The well-established role for PI3Kδ in the co-stimulation of T:B cell interactions is complemented by a secondary mechanism by which δ activity acts as a negative regulator of IgE class switching.(12) Studies exploring immune response to tumors have, in addition to mediation by PI3Kδ, also identified PI3Kγ as a central node within the signaling cascade stimulating growth factor and Toll-like receptor activation.(13) Furthermore, PI3Kδ has shown clinical relevance in B cell malignancies, where 1 (an inhibitor of PI3Kδ) dampened the responsiveness of the tumor cells to supportive stimuli from the microenvironment.(14)
    Numerous examples of innate immune cells show coordinated signaling through both PI3Kγ and δ isoforms for complete functionality. Both isoforms are required for effective mast cell function, where PI3Kδ features downstream of survival signals from c-kit and as part of the FcεR1-mediated degranulation cascade,(15) whereas PI3Kγ potentiates the initial IgE signal both via PKCβ and via paracrine release of adenosine to affect full degranulation. PI3Kγ signaling is essential for the appropriate distribution of mast cells to inflamed tissue.(16) Neutrophils primed with TNFα move in two phases; the first (chemokinetic) phase is driven by PI3Kγ-mediated PIP3 accumulation at the leading edge of the cell, while the subsequent second (chemotactic) phase is dependent on PI3Kδ.(17−19) We have further demonstrated roles for both PI3Kγ and δ in neutrophil degranulation and superoxide generation, respectively.(20) These findings have led to the development of a first wave of selective PI3Kδ inhibitors as a more subtle immune modulatory therapy aimed at fine-tuning neutrophilic host defense. The therapeutic hypothesis was based upon rejuvenation of effective directionality in neutrophil movement and therefore a reduction in “collateral damage” observed in a neutrophil with upregulated PI3Kδ.(21) This hypothesis is intriguing, as it focuses on effective neutrophil function in tissue to minimize potential liabilities attributed to immune suppression.
    Early preclinical work highlighted risks of reduced resistance to infection with PI3Kγ knock-down.(22) More recently, however, subtler effects of PI3Kγ inhibition on viral infections have been observed.(23) In contrast, although there is little preclinical data linking inhibition of PI3Kδ with infection, in clinical studies of 1 with cancer patients, a significantly increased risk of infection relative to controls, including fatalities, has been observed.(24,25) Infections have also been observed as a significant side effect of treatment with the PI3Kγδ inhibitor 15.(26) Clinical studies with PI3Kγ inhibitors are at a much earlier stage than PI3Kδ inhibitors, so it is too early to say how they will fare under similar circumstances. We are yet to understand the significance of systemic PI3Kδ inhibitor safety vs the interconnected pathologic roles for both PI3Kγ and δ pathways, which may be safely inhibited through local antagonism (e.g., inhalation for respiratory diseases). A second wave of mixed PI3Kγδ inhibitors will now address the efficacy and safety profiles of PI3Kγδ inhibitors in comparison to selective PI3Kδ inhibitors in the clinic.

    PI3Kγ, PI3Kδ, and Dual PI3Kγδ Inhibitors under Clinical Development

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Since the 2012 Perspective, several PI3K inhibitors have progressed to clinical development and the oral inhibitor idelalisib (1) has been approved in oncology (note added after review: Duvelisib (15) has now also been approved in oncology by the U.S. FDA). An overview of the different PI3K inhibitors and their development status will be discussed in this section.

    PI3Kδ Selective Inhibitors

    Several inhibitors of PI3Kδ are being developed in oncology, respiratory diseases, immunodeficiency, and autoimmunity. To date, the most advanced oral selective inhibitor of PI3Kδ is idelalisib (1, Zydelig, Gilead Sciences), which has been launched for the treatment of cancer, more specifically for relapsed chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL), relapsed follicular B-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma, relapsed small lymphocytic lymphoma (SLL), and leukemia. Several additional cancer indications are also being investigated in phase 1 and phase 2, but no development has been reported for 1 in inflammatory diseases. Although 1 is recognized as an effective drug, a pattern of unpredictable immune-mediated toxicity has led to a black box warning in the U.S., which is limiting its current use as immunomodulating agent.(27)
    Another advanced oral PI3Kδ inhibitor currently in phase 3 is umbralisib (2, also referred to as TGR-1202, Rhizen Pharmaceuticals). Several combination studies are ongoing, and the current registration-directed phase 2b/3 study in patients with previously treated diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (UNITY-DLBCL trial(28)) is investigating the efficacy of the compound alone and with ublituximab (TG-1101 iv; CD20 antibody). A triple combination arm with TG-1101, 2, and bendamustine has also been added recently after a successful interim analysis (UNITY-NHL trial(29)). In 2017, the combination of 2 and TG-1101 was granted orphan drug designation by the FDA for the treatment of patients with CLL, and regulatory filing is expected in 2018.(30) Additionally, the 2/ublituximab duo is also being evaluated against a combination of 2, obinutuzumab, and chlorambucil (UNITY-CLL trial).(31)
    In oncology, AMG-319 (3, Amgen, also known as ACP319),(32,33) INCB-050465 (putative structure 4, parsaclisib, Incyte Corporation),(34) HMPL-689 (5, Hutchisson China MediTech, structure not disclosed),(35) and ME-401/PWT-143 (6, MEI Pharma),(36,37) all orally available compounds, are active or have completed phase 1 programs. In addition, 3, and 4 have progressed to phase 2 for head and neck cancer (3) or various lymphomas and myelofibrosis (4). MEI Pharma has also communicated their intention to start a phase 3 registration trial with 6 in patients with relapsed/refractory follicular lymphoma in 2018.(38) Another compound from Incyte Corporation, dezapelisib (7), which started clinical development in 2013, is reported to have been discontinued, with the exception of one trial in subjects with previously treated B-cell malignancies, which is expected to be completed in May 2019.(39)
    Two additional PI3Kδ inhibitors, both from Gilead Sciences, GS9901 (8, oncology, phase 1) and acalisib (9, oncology, phase 2), have been in clinical trials; however no further progress has been reported since 2017.
    Two inhaled compounds in development are nemiralisib (10) and GSK-2292767 (11). Currently in phase 2, 10 is being developed for the treatment of asthma(40) and COPD(41) but also toward activated PI3Kδ syndrome/p110 δ activating mutation causing senescent T cells, lymphadenopathy, and immunodeficiency (APDS/PASLI)(42) and bronchiectasis (the latter a phase 1 study). The second compound, 11, is also being developed for asthma and COPD; a phase 1 study in healthy smokers was completed in 2017.(43) The results of a phase 2a study with 10 in patients with persistent, uncontrolled asthma were recently published and demonstrated that 10 inhibited PI3Kδ locally in the lung but that this inhibition did not translate into meaningful clinical improvement in this patient population.(44) On the other hand, recent positive results in the COPD phase 2a study with 10, based on imaging studies, led to further investment in a phase 2b trial in COPD.(45) Development for COPD has been confirmed in April 2018.
    Leniosilib (12, Novartis) and seletalisib (13, UCB Celltech), two oral PI3Kδ selective inhibitors, have entered clinical development in rare autoimmune and immunodeficiency diseases, where both compounds have reached phase 3 for APDS/PASLI(46,47) and phase 2 for Sjögren syndrome.(48,49) Compounds 12(50) and 13(51) have both been granted orphan drug designation from the FDA for APDS; compound 12 has also received orphan designation in the EU (2018).(52)

    PI3Kγ Selective Inhibitors

    Infinity Pharmaceuticals have initiated clinical development of their PI3Kγ selective inhibitor IPI-549 (14) as an immuno-oncology treatment targeting myeloid cells. Compound 14 is an oral PI3Kγ inhibitor currently in phase 1/1b for the treatment of subjects with advanced solid cancers.(53) Compound 14 is also being tested as a combination therapy with nivolumab, a PD-1 inhibitor,(54) as well as in triple-combination studies with different assets from Arcus Biosciences.(55)
    Inhibition of PI3Kγ by 14 can inhibit myeloid cells from modifying the microenvironment that promotes tumor regrowth. It is therefore hoped that 14 may be especially meaningful in preventing spread and recurrence of malignant disease, particularly following initial treatment with chemotherapy and radiation therapy.(56)

    Dual PI3Kγδ Inhibitors

    Dual PI3Kγδ inhibitors are being developed in oncology (Verastem Oncology and Rhizen Pharmaceuticals), as well as in respiratory diseases (RespiVert Ltd. and AstraZeneca).
    In oncology duvelisib (15, Copiktra, Verastem Oncology, licensed from Infinity Pharmaceuticals) is the most advanced dual PI3Kγδ inhibitor and it has recently been approved in the U.S. for the treatment of adult patients with relapsed/refractory chronic lymphocytic leukemia/small lymphocytic lymphoma (CLL/SLL) or relapsed/refractory follicular lymphoma. EU filing for CLL is expected by the end of 2018.(57) Compound 15 was also a candidate for asthma and rheumatoid arthritis, but further development in nononcologic diseases has been stopped. In a trial involving an allergen challenge with mild asthmatic patients 15 missed the primary end point (maximum decrease in allergen-induced FEV1 changes). Significant effects were seen, however, against a range of secondary end points, such as a reduction of exhaled nitric oxide, decreased sensitivity to methacholine treatment, and decreases in biomarkers for the asthmatic inflammatory response.(58) These effects were observed at the highest dose of 25 mg b.i.d., the current dose approved in oncology with a black box warning in the U.S., and demonstrated that systemic administration of 15 could have positive effect on parameters relevant to asthma but that an inhalation-based drug delivery is probably needed to overcome the adverse effect seen with systemic PI3K inhibitors.(59) Similarly, for rheumatoid arthritis, 15 failed to provide any added benefit compared to placebo.(60)
    Tenalisib (16, Rhizen Pharmaceuticals) is currently studied in combination with pembrolizumab (phase 2) for the treatment of classical Hodgkin’s lymphomas.(61) Compound 16 has received orphan drug designation and expedited review designation from the FDA for the treatment of peripheral and cutaneous T-cell lymphoma.(62)
    In respiratory diseases, RespiVert has completed two phase 1 studies in asthmatics(63,64) and one in COPD patients for their compound RV1729 (17)(65,66) as well as an additional phase 1 study with a second compound, RV6153 (putative structure 18).(67) No further development has been reported recently for either compound. AstraZeneca has initiated a phase 1 study of inhaled AZD8154 (19, asthma, structure not disclosed) in healthy subjects.(68)

    Toxicity of PI3Kγ, PI3Kδ, and Dual PI3Kγδ Inhibitors

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Table 1 summarizes safety data/adverse events reported from ongoing or completed clinical trials.
    Table 1. Safety Data/Adverse Events Reported from Clinical Trials
    compdinhibitor/isoformstudy phasepatient populationdosing information on PI3K inhibitoradverse events AE ≥ grade 3 (grade 3 = severe or medically significant but not immediately life-threatening)
    1PI3Kδ1Relapsed or refractory CLL50–350 mg q.d. or b.i.d., po for 48 weeksPneumonia (20%), neutropenic fever (11%), diarrhea (6%), pyrexia (4%), cough (4%), fatigue (2%), transaminitis (2%), no reported dose-limiting toxicities(69)
    1 + various doublet and triplet combinations of chemotherapy and monoclonal antibodiesPI3Kδ1bRelapsed and refractory CLL150 mg b.i.d., po in 3–12 28-day cyclesNeutropenia, thrombocytopenia, diarrhea, transaminitis(69)
    1 + rituximabPI3Kδ2Treatment-naive older patients with CLL or small lymphocytic leukemia150 mg b.i.d., po for 48 weeksDiarrhea/colitis, rash, pyrexia, nausea, chills, cough, fatigue, elevated AST (aspartate aminotransferase)/ALT (alanine aminotransferase)(70)
    1 + rituximabPI3Kδ3Previously treated recurrent CLL150 mg b.i.d., po (the study was stopped early due to overwhelming efficacy)Neutropenia (37%), thrombocytopenia (11%), anemia (7%), pneumonia (8%), transaminitis (8%), diarrhea/colitis (5%), pneumonitis (4%)(69)
    1 + ofatumumabPI3Kδ3Previously treated CLL150 mg b.i.d., po for 24 weeksDiarrhea/colitis (20%), pneumonia (13%), febrile neutropenia (12%)(69)
    1 + bendamustine + rituximabPI3Kδ3Untreated CLL150 mg b.i.d., poTerminated due to an increased rate of severe adverse events (SAEs) including deaths, mostly due to infections(71)
    1 + rituximabPI3Kδ3Previously treated indolent non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL)150 mg b.i.d., poTerminated due to an increased rate of SAEs including deaths, mostly due to infections(71)
    1 + rituximab or chlorambucilPI3Kδ3Untreated CLL100 or 150 mg b.i.d., poTerminated due to an increased rate of deaths and SAEs(72)
    2PI3Kδ1Relapsed or refractory CLL, small lymphocytic lymphoma, B-cell and T-cell NHL, Hodgkin’s lymphoma50, 100, 200, 400, 800, 1200, 1800 mg q.d., po in 28-day cyclesNeutropenia (13%), anemia (9%), thrombocytopenia (7%), pneumonia (3%), lung infection (1%), fibrile neutropenia (1%), colitis (2%)(73)
    2PI3Kδ2Intolerant to prior ibrutinib (Bruton tyrosine kinase inhibitor) or 1 (PI3Kδ inhibitor) treatment800 mg q.d., po6% discontinuing due to AE(74)
    4PI3KδI/2Previously treated indolent/aggressive B-cell NHL and Hodgkin’s lymphoma5–45 mg b.i.d., poNausea (38%), diarrhea (31%), vomiting (25%). 40% SAEs most frequently colitis, diarrhea, hypotension. 25% discontinued due to AEs(75)
    6PI3Kδ1bCLL, small lymphocytic lymphoma, follicular lymphoma60, 120, 180 mg b.i.d., poNeutropenia, no patients had discontinued due to AEs (May 2017)(76)
    9PI3Kδ1bRecurrent lymphoid malignancies50, 100, 200, 400 mg b.i.d., poDiarrhea (10%), rash (10%), elevated liver transaminases (5%), infections (13%)(77)
    10PI3Kδ2Acute exacerbation of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) (in addition to standard of care)1000 μg q.d., inhaled for 12-weeksCoronary artery stenosis (2%), pneumonia (2%), other lung infection (2%), blood sodium decreased (2%), cough (35%)(78)
    14 or 14 + nivolumabPI3Kγ1/1bAdvanced solid tumors20, 30, 40 mg q.d., poRash and AST/ALT increase (14 + nivolumab)(79)
    15Dual PI3Kγδ1CLL, indolent NHL, or mantle cell lymphoma25 mg b.i.d., poCytopenias, liver enzyme elevations, diarrhea, rash, pneumonia. No dose-related trends in adverse events(80)
    15Dual PI3Kγδ1Relapsed or refractory peripheral (PTCL) or cutaneous (CTCL) T-cell lymphoma25, 50, 60, 75, 100 mg b.i.d., po in 28-day cyclesTransaminase increases (40% alanine aminotransferase, 17% aspartate aminotransferase), maculopapular rash (17%), neutropenia (17%), pneumonias/lung infections (20%), colitis (11%), pyrexia (9%)(26)
    15Dual PI3Kγδ2Refractory indolent NHL25 mg b.i.d., po in 28-day cycles, up to 13 cyclesInfections of all types, pneumonitis (9%), colitis (5%)(80)
    15Dual PI3Kγδ3Relapsed or refractory CLL or small lymphocytic lymphoma25 mg b.i.d., po initial 21-day cycle followed by 28-day cycles for up to 18 cycles with potential addition of cyclesNeutropenia, anemia, diarrhea, pneumonia, colitis(80)
    Safety data from clinical trials with different selective PI3Kδ inhibitors demonstrate similar adverse event profiles. Neutropenia, thrombocytopenia, anemia, transaminitis, diarrhea/colitis, and pneumonia/pneumonitis were the most frequent grade ≥3 adverse events observed. The U.S. FDA prescribing information for 1 contains a black box warning for fatal and/or severe diarrhea or colitis, hepatotoxicity, pneumonitis, and intestinal perforation. An expert panel reviewed the pathology of these treatment-emergent adverse events (TEAEs) and proposed key management tools for patients receiving 1 therapy.(81) Compound 1 should not be used concomitantly with other hepatotoxic drugs, and serum transaminase levels should be evaluated at regular intervals during treatment to identify signs of hepatotoxicity. Any patient presenting pulmonary symptoms should be evaluated for pneumonitis. Overall, although the U.S. FDA prescribing information carries black box warnings for fatal and/or severe diarrhea or colitis, hepatotoxicity, and pneumonitis, their risk and severity have the potential to be mitigated through proper identification and management.(81) EMA announced in March 2016 the recommendation of new safety measures for 1. EMA’s Pharmacovigilance Risk Assessment Committee (PRAC) recommends that all patients treated with 1 should receive antibiotics to prevent a particular type of lung infection. Patients should also be monitored for infection and have regular blood tests for white cell counts because low counts can increase their risk of infection. Compound 1 should not be started in patients with a generalized infection. These are provisional recommendations that the PRAC has issued, as a precaution, to protect patients while the medicine is being reviewed. The review started after a higher rate of serious adverse events was seen in three clinical trials among patients receiving 1 compared with placebo.(82) Less information is currently available for selective PI3Kγ inhibitors, but data indicate a potentially favorable toxicity profile compared to PI3Kδ inhibitors. Reported safety data on one dual PI3Kγδ inhibitor (15) indicate similar toxicity as for a selective PI3Kδ inhibitor. Careful monitoring is required when dosing these kinds of inhibitors to patients to ensure adequate management of adverse events.

    Medicinal Chemistry of PI3K Inhibitors “Propeller” Shaped Inhibitors 6,6-Fused Systems

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    The first truly selective PI3Kδ inhibitor, 1, had what has been described(83) as a propeller shape with three “blades” at an angle of approximately 120° to each other. These “blades” consist of a central core heterocycle, typically a bicyclic aromatic system, a hinge binding moiety linked to the core by one or two atoms that allows it to adopt an orthogonal arrangement, and a “third blade”, typically, though not exclusively, an aromatic ring. This type of molecule gained selectivity through access to an induced pocket that was preferentially formed in the δ isoform. Medicinal chemists worldwide have subsequently varied this theme. No fewer than 13 of the 19 compounds that have proceeded to clinical trials have a structure that belongs to this class. (For details of the protein structures of PI3K enzymes and the ways that isoform selectivity relates to inhibitor structure see the section Structural Determinants Driving Selectivity toward PI3Kγ or δ below).
    The most successful core structures for propeller-shaped inhibitors have been 6,6-fused ring systems, pioneered by the quinazolinone of 1. ICOS, and their successors at Gilead, further explored the quinazolinone core (8, 9).(84,85) RespiVert also used this core, though, targeting inhaled administration, their molecules look quite different (17, 18);(86,87)17 has a more marked dual PI3Kγδ inhibition profile than 18, showing subtle differences of isoform selectivity between apparently quite minor structural changes (Table 2).
    Table 2. 6,6-Fused Propeller Inhibitorsa
      IC50 (nM)fold selectivity 
    compdoriginatorPI3KδPI3Kγα/δβ/δcell IC50 (nM)
    1(98)Gilead2.5893302308b
    2(90)Rhizen14>120>1000>54 
    3(91)Amgen188501800150 
    8(84)Gilead11907501001c
    9(85)Gilead 3000d>1000e63f19g
    13(92)UCB1228030018016h
    15(88)Infinity2.527640340.36i
    16(89)Rhizen2533>400160 
    17(86)RespiVert122516 1.1j
    18(87)RespiVert2.528560020007.4j
    20(93)Nanjing1.45.711060 
    21(94)Lupin0.1–10    
    22(95)Lupin1–10090–2000500–5000k75–3000k 
    23(96)Zhejiang University0–20347901706l
    24(97)Chiesi<10>1000>100>100 
    a

    The asterisk ∗ in the above table section containing drawn chemical structures indicates undefined absolute stereochemistry.

    b

    Basophils.

    c

    Human whole blood.

    d

    Basophils (fMLP stimulation).

    e

    SW3T3 cells stimulated with PDGF.

    f

    Mouse embryonic fibroblasts.

    g

    Basophils (anti FcεR1 stimulation).

    h

    fMLP stimulated release of superoxide from neutrophils.

    i

    RAJI cells.

    j

    U937 cells.

    k

    Ranges in nM given, not fold selectivity.

    l

    SU-DHL cells.

    Intellikine pioneered the isosteric isoquinolinone core; their first compound, the dual PI3Kγδ inhibitor 15,(88) was licensed by Infinity, who subsequently made further modifications to give the selective PI3Kγ inhibitor 14.(56) It is worth noting that, though described as a dual PI3Kγδ inhibitor, 15 has an 11-fold potency difference for PI3Kδ vs PI3Kγ and only 3-fold greater potency for PI3Kγ than for PI3Kβ.
    Rhizen Pharmaceuticals chose a chromenone core as an alternative fused 6,6-ring system for their two development candidates (2, 16);(89,90) despite the apparent structural similarity between 1, 9, and 16, there is a notable difference in selectivity toward PI3Kγ. Compound 16 is essentially equipotent at γ and δ, while 1 and 9 are more than 100-fold δ-selective (on the enzyme level). It is surprising that 16, without the additional aryl ring in the affinity pocket, is more potent than 2.
    Amgen and UCB used a quinoline core for their candidates (3, 13);(91,92) the additional lipophilicity of this system compared to the quinazolinone may explain why both feature pyridine rings as their “3rd blade”.
    Since 2011 there have been additional variations on the 6,6-fused theme. Nanjing chemists claimed a quinolinone with the carbonyl group in a different orientation (20),(93) while Lupin have produced two patents with a quinolizin-4-one core (21, 22).(94,95) The second of these patents includes an additional aryl group that is unique among PI3Kδ inhibitors; however given the broad activity ranges given for PI3K inhibition in the patent, it is impossible to judge the potency or selectivity that these variations provide. Zheijiang University have described a benzothiadiazine dioxide based class of inhibitors (23).(96) One additional 6,6-fused ring system has appeared in the period reviewed, the isochromenone ring used by Chiesi in a 2015 patent (24);(97) however it appears that these compounds must adopt a somewhat different orientation in the binding pocket, possibly with the tetrahydropyridine ring adopting a similar orientation to the fluorophenyl of 22.

    “Propeller” Shaped Inhibitors: 5,6- and 6,5-Fused Systems

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    5,6-Fused systems (7, 25–33) allow for a wide range of heterocycles to be investigated; these include the first Incyte clinical candidate (7)(99) and, potentially, the clinical candidate of Hutchison, 5, which may well be related to 26 or 27 (Table 3).
    Table 3. 5,6-Fused Propeller Inhibitorsa
      IC50 (nM)fold selectivity 
    compdoriginatorPI3KδPI3Kγα/δβ/δcell IC50 (nM)
    7(99)Incyte31230093012035b
    25(100)Almirall2.6   7.8c
    26(101)Hutchison242∼500∼500 
    27(102)Hutchison43250250 
    28(103)Hutchison0.3383000290 
    29(104)Ye<20   <20d
    30(105)Qianwan0.287160001400 
    31(106)Takeda0.7    
    32(107)Fochon    36d
    33(108)AstraZeneca0.5>200>13013010e
    a

    The asterisk ∗ in the above table section containing drawn chemical structures indicates undefined absolute stereochemistry.

    b

    Basophils.

    c

    THP-1 cells.

    d

    SU-DHL-6 cells.

    e

    Jeko-1 cells.

    Almirall has described in detail the discovery and SAR exploration around pyrrolotriazinone 25.(100) This compound has good PK and was optimized to minimize metabolism-related safety risks. Hutchison utilized the same ring system, though in their case a cyclized linker between the hinge-binding motif and the central bicycle provides structural differentiation (26, 27).(101,102) The second of their patents discloses a highly dual selective PI3Kγδ inhibitor (27).
    Hutchison further described an imidazopyridazine core (28),(103) while a closely related pyrazolopyrimidine core has been claimed by Ye (29);(104) related series of imidazopyridines by Qianwan (30)(105) and pyrrolopyridines by Takeda (31)(106) have also been claimed.
    In another case of two companies working on the same heterocyclic system, Shanghai Fochon (32)(107) and AstraZeneca (33)(108) have both disclosed thiazolopyridone cores, though in AstraZeneca’s case these molecules were significantly extended around the “3rd blade”.
    Investigation of 6,5-fused systems has given fewer PI3Kδ inhibitor classes (34, 35, Table 4). In these compounds the fused ring takes an intermediate position relative to the hinge-binding group as compared to 1 and similar compounds and the alternative orientation exemplified by 24. Earlier examples of compounds of this subtype appeared in 2011 (Amgen and Incyte) followed in 2012 by compounds from Almirall (34)(109) and then later, in a more elaborate example (35, 2015), from Chiesi. In this latter patent(110) it appears, from the limited data given, that isoform selectivity is more challenging in this subseries with a tendency to pan inhibition or PI3Kγ selectivity. This may explain why there are fewer ring systems described and no examples in development.
    Table 4. Data for 6,5-Fused Propeller Inhibitorsa
      IC50 (nM)
    compdoriginatorPI3KδPI3Kγ
    34Almirall(109)11 
    35bChiesi(110)10–1000<10
    a

    The asterisk ∗ in the above table section containing drawn chemical structures indicates undefined absolute stereochemistry.

    b

    PI3Kα and β IC50 of 10–1000 nM.

    Other “Propeller” Shaped Inhibitors

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Significant changes to the “propeller” structure have been pioneered by Incyte who have removed the fused ring altogether (36, 37, Table 5);(111,112) the optimized compound of this type appears to be the highly isoform selective compound 4(113) (PI3Kα, β and γ IC50 ∼ 20 μM) which is advancing in clinical trials. A later patent describes a further series where a new ring is fused (38).(114) Chiesi have subsequently reported a nonfused “propeller” core (39)(115) that appears to be a development of their previous 5,6-fused series (35).
    Table 5. Data for Nonfused Propeller Inhibitorsa
      IC50 (nM)
    compdoriginatorPI3Kδcell
    4(113)Incyte10.15b
    36(111)Incyte<50<50c
    37(112)Incyte<20<20c
    38(114)Incyte<100<500d
    39(115)Chiesi<1000 
    a

    The asterisk ∗ in the above table section containing drawn chemical structures indicates undefined absolute stereochemistry.

    b

    B-cells.

    c

    Pfeiffer cells.

    d

    SUDHL cells.

    Hinge Binding Groups for Propeller Inhibitors

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    In addition to variation of the core propeller structure, the molecules have been investigated across all other regions. For the kinase hinge binding motif the earliest examples feature 6-substituted purines, typically adenine. Attachment was initially through the 9-position via a simple methylene linker (40, IC87114 a widely used tool compound)(116) until the alternative orientation 6-substition, and an (S)-configured alkyl linker (for example 1, 3, 7, 9, 15, 16) was identified. The linker between the hinge and the core heterocycle appears to enforce a suitable stereochemical relationship between the core and the hinge of the molecule; Chiesi(117) have reported a study where they looked at 40 and methyl substituted analogues (41, 42) where atropisomeric forms could be isolated and correlated their potencies with conformational calculations and a published X-ray crystal structure of 40 in PI3Kδ. A clear preference for S configuration was observed (more active atropisomers for 40, 41, and 42Ki = 13, 13, 1.6 nM) with an additional effect of atropisomerism from the pendant ortho-tolyl group. The S-configured isomer (42) had an energy minimum that almost exactly matched the conformation of 40 from the crystal structure in PI3Kδ;(83) none of the low-energy conformations of the R-isomer 41 were similar (Figure 7).
    Overall purines remained the preferred hinge binding residue until the identification of cyanopyrimidines by Amgen in 2010 (43 (Figure 8), PI3Kδ 5 nM compared to the corresponding purine analogue as a racemate, PI3Kδ 80 nM).(118) This heterocyclic system was widely adopted in later publications.
    Variation of the hinge-binder has been described in detail for three different series in recent papers.(56,100,119) Almirall report extensive exploration of both the hinge binding group and the linking alkylene moiety (Table 6).(100) For the alkylene moiety, S-methyl (44) was judged optimal, though ethyl (45) or cyclization to a pyrrolidine (46) was tolerated; other groups, including Hutchison (26, 27) and Novartis(120) (58, Figure 9, IC50 PI3Kδ 8 nM, γ 4.1 nM) have also reported cyclized linkers. Hydroxyl substitution on the alkyl group (47, 48) was tolerated, but addition of trifluoromethyl (49) was deleterious. Monocyclic and bicyclic hinge binders with 0, 1, or 2 hydrogen bond donors and some fluorine or cyano substituents were evaluated. Bicyclic groups (53–57) are comparable to monocyclic in terms of potency (44, 50–52); however there was a strong effect from addition of electron-withdrawing substituents (CN> CF3> F > H; 44, 50, 51, 52; 54, 55). Although a diaminopurine hinge-binder (56) was the most potent in the enzyme assay, the cyanopyrimidine (44) was the most potent in a cell assay; this compound was also more stable metabolically and was retained in the key compound (25, LAS191954).(100)
    Table 6. Data from Almirall for Variations of Linker and Hinge Binding Group(100)
        IC50 (nM)
    compdparentR1R2 hingePI3Kδcella
    44AMeC4.34.7
    45AEtC1118
    46B C4.66.6
    47ACH2CH2OHC4.816
    48ACH2OHC1351
    49ACH2CF3C6101600
    50AMeD1200 
    51AMeE73210
    52AMeF12 
    53AMeG107
    54AMeH52150
    55AMeI947
    56AMeJ3.16.5
    57AMeK60 
    a

    THP-1 cells.

    In contrast the Gilead group observed for their quinazolinone series that, although the cyanopyrimidine gave excellent potency, metabolism of this moiety by aldehyde oxidase became a problem. This issue was ultimately solved by replacement with a diaminopyrimidine (59).(119) Further optimization of this structure led to the clinical candidate (8)(84) (Table 7).
    Table 7. Data for Propeller Inhibitors with Modified Hinge Binding Groups
       fold selectivity 
    compdoriginatorPI3Kδ IC50 (nM)α/δβ/δγ/δcell IC50 (nM)
    8Gilead17501001901a
    59Gilead2.219006501801a
    a

    Human whole blood.

    Other hinge binders reported in the patent literature, but without any discussion of their pros and cons, lack an H-bond donor function (13, 27).(102,121) Interestingly these compounds show sufficient binding without one of the groups usually regarded as essential; the only published data on this replacement however are from a single example in the Almirall work cited above,(100) where a pyrazolopyrimidine (57) showed similar potency (60 nM) to the nearest analogue with a donor (54, 52 nM). The metabolic stability of 57 was poor however.
    Finally, Infinity have described the investigation of alternative hinge binding groups to promote selectivity for PI3Kγ over PI3Kδ.(56) The preferred hinge binder has an unusual acceptor–donor pair with an aminoheterocycle as the donor and an amide carbonyl group as acceptor. This hinge binder is part of clinical candidate 14 and will be further discussed below under PI3Kγ inhibitors.
    Since the first report by the Shokat group in 2006,(122) several groups have added to the hinge binding moiety to pick up additional interactions deeper in the affinity pocket (Table 8). At least in some cases, this also led to increased PI3Kγ affinity (Table 8). Following the first compound PIK 294 (60) Almirall, Gilead, and others have incorporated pyrazolopyrimidines (4, 17, 18, 24, 35, 39) and subsequently explored other vectors building out from aminopyrimidines (61–63)(123−125) and aminopyrrolopyrimidines (64, 65).(126,127)
    Table 8. Data for Propeller Inhibitors with Additional Substitution on Hinge Binding Groups
       fold selectivity
    compdoriginatorPI3Kδ IC50 (nM)α/δβ/δγ/δ
    60UCSF1010000490160
    61Almirall0.2   
    62Sunshine Lake2>150034019
    63Gilead<100>10>10>10
    64Almirall0.04   
    65Almirall0.43   

    The “3rd Blade”

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    In early compounds the “3rd blade” of the propeller was typically phenyl (1, 15) though the original disclosure of this series back in 2001(128) included examples with aliphatic, alicyclic, saturated heterocycles and benzylic groups in this position. Quite quickly fluorination of the phenyl, particularly meta fluorination, was identified as beneficial (2, 7, 16). Alternatively, pyridyl (3, 8) or pyridine N-oxide (13) replacements of phenyl and N-benzyl substituents (17, 18) were used. Subsequently it was demonstrated that a very wide range of groups are tolerated in this position (Table 9). This residue acts as a conformational lock on the two key parts of the molecule, the hinge binder and the core. Examples of diverse groups at this position include further aromatic heterocyclic (66, 67),(129,130) saturated heterocyclic (68, 69),(131,132) and cyclopropyl groups (70,(124) compare to 62). AstraZeneca used the meta position of the phenyl residue to explore a variety of basic groups (33)(108) that affected pKa and lipophilicity and thus lung retention and cell activity of the compounds. In the case of 67, activity at PI3Kβ was similar to PI3Kδ (modeling showed formation of a hydrogen bond to Asp856 of PI3Kβ); AstraZeneca further observed increased PI3Kβ activity with less hindered amines in their series.
    Table 9. Data for Propeller Inhibitors with Changes to the “3rd Blade”
       fold selectivity 
    compdoriginatorPI3Kδ IC50 (nM)α/δβ/δγ/δcell IC50 (nM)
    66Takeda6.9    
    67Gilead5.31601.5>190020a
    68Roche0.852500  29b
    69Gilead1 62>10000 
    70Sunshine Lake12803374 
    71Infinity1942017031013c
    a

    PC3 cells.

    b

    Human peripheral blood mononuclear cells.

    c

    Raji cells.

    Infinity then migrated the residue to another ring position, and, despite the significant structural difference, the compound showed high selectivity for PI3Kδ inhibition (71).(133)

    Second (Fused) Ring of the Core

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    The second fused ring of the core is most commonly substituted in the 5-position (quinazolinone numbering) or equivalent. The other positions have generally been left unsubstituted, though halogens, particularly fluorine, have been attached (note 6-F substitution on 2, 3, 9); the PK optimization leading to 8 shows the options.(84) Many of the groups attached to the “5”-position have been small. 5-Aryl substitutions (58, 72, 73; Table 10), however, were pioneered by Infinity but have also been adopted by other groups; this additional substitution contributes to the excellent PI3Kδ-selectivity profile of 72, though 58 is much less selective against PI3Kγ. Substitution via an acetylene linker has been successful for attaching a variety of groups, principally heterocycles, of which 14 is the most notable example; it appears to contribute to the high PI3Kγ-selectivity observed. Aliphatic groups have been attached too, such as those of 17 and 18; in these two the acetylenic group may be contributing to PI3Kγ-potency for the dual PI3Kγδ-inhibition (17) but may also be important for obtaining the desired physicochemical properties for inhaled administration.
    Table 10. Data for Substitutions on the Fused Ring
       fold selectivity 
    compdoriginatorPI3Kδ IC50 (nM)α/δβ/δγ/δcell IC50 (nM)
    72Infinity<100>1000a>1000a<100a<100b
    73Yuhan1160010000650 
    a

    Value in nM.

    b

    B-cell proliferation.

    One additional subclass of propeller-shaped compound in the patent literature is deuterated analogues of clinical compounds. Patents have been published claiming analogues of both 1(134−136) and 15,(137) with deuterium replacing one or more hydrogen atoms. In one case there is evidence of improved pharmacokinetic half-life in preclinical species.(135)

    Selectivity of Propeller Inhibitors

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Isoform selectivity of propeller-shaped molecules is not always easy to assess. There is limited data available in patents, and comparison of assays from different sources is not straightforward, particularly where ATP concentrations vary. Nevertheless, for those compounds with published data, a range of different selectivity profiles is evident. The reported compounds are often PI3Kδ-selective, though the degree of selectivity varies considerably. Of the compounds for which data are available, only 4, 8, 28, 30, 33, 59, 71, and 73 are >100-fold selective against all three other isoforms at the enzyme level. 15, 16, and 17 are described as PI3Kγδ dual inhibitors, though for 15 there is an approximately 10-fold difference between the potency at both isoforms; in the cases of 15 (PI3Kβ, 34-fold vs δ, 3-fold vs γ) and 17 (PI3Kα, 16-fold vs δ, 8-fold vs γ; no value reported for β), a third isoform is also inhibited within 10-fold of the weaker activity (Table 11). Other compounds inhibit either PI3Kγ or β with selectivities of 10- to 100-fold vs PI3Kδ. Given that effective selectivity depends on the level of activity at an undesired target at the peak concentration, while the desired target typically needs to be inhibited at trough concentration, the PK profile of each compound will have as significant an impact on the likelihood of effects from inhibition of undesired isoforms as the in vitro isoform selectivities. The exception to the PI3Kδ selective profile is 14 which exhibits >200-fold selectivity for PI3Kγ against all three other isoforms, a remarkable turnaround, based on the combination of altering both the hinge binder and addition of the acetylene linked heterocycle.
    Table 11. Selectivity of Dual PI3Kγδ Inhibitors Based on PI3Kγ activity
     fold selectivity
    compdα/δβ/δ
    15583
    16310120
    178no data
    Beyond PI3K isoform selectivity there have been disclosures for multiple advanced compounds on their selectivity against both wider panels of kinases and other targets (Table 12). In contrast to protein kinase inhibitors, where achieving selectivity with ATP competitive inhibitors is often highly challenging, for these propeller-shaped PI3K inhibitors protein kinase selectivity is excellent for all reported examples, with only two examples showing even modest activity, each at a single protein kinase. Even toward other lipid kinases selectivity is always good; the class III PI3K Vps34 is the most common off-target but with a large margin compared to PI3K inhibition.
    Table 12. Selectivity Profiles for Propeller-Shaped PI3K Inhibitors
    compdno. of kinases screened (concn)kinase hits
    1(98)402 (10 μM)Vps34 IC50 = 0.98 μM
    2(138)359 (1 μM) protein kinasescasein kinase 1ε, >60% at 1 μM
    3(91)359 (10 μM) 
    8(84)456 (10 μM) (56 mutant kinases, 11 lipid kinases) 
    9(85)lipid kinases (undefined concn)Vps34 IC50 = 2.5 μM
    14(56)468 (1 μM)DNAPK IC50 = 4.8 μM; Vps34 IC50 = 40 μM; SIK 88% inhibition at 1 μM
    15(88)442 (1 μM) (includes lipid kinases and 56 mutant kinases) 
    25(100)“extensive panel of protein and lipid kinases” 
    33(108)345 (1 μM) 
    67(130)456 (10 μM) 

    “Nonpropeller” Shaped Inhibitors Indazole Hinge-Binders

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    GSK has published the discovery of a series with an indazole hinge binder (74)(139) by selective optimization of side activities from a series that originated as PIM kinase inhibitors and was also investigated against GSK3β. This series was optimized to two compounds (10, 11)(140) with excellent isoform selectivity that have been taken forward to clinical trials as inhaled agents for the treatment of asthma and/or COPD (Table 13). Compound 10 exhibits very good isoform selectivity and excellent cell potency that translated into good in vivo potency. Compound 11 was selected because of a beneficial pharmacokinetic profile (higher systemic clearance, very low oral bioavailability) and improved selectivity for the hERG ion channel and thus reduced risk of cardiovascular side effects. GSK, in collaboration with Strathclyde University, has further used this template to develop the only reported covalent inhibitors of PI3Kδ (75).(141) In a another extension of this work GSK has reported modifying the indazole hinge-binding group to a benzofuran that, coupled with other modifications, converts the series from one suitable for inhalation to a series targeting oral administration (76).(142) Finally, a further GSK patent has appeared with another follow-up compound (77) to this series using a different template but retaining some features from the earlier compounds.(143)
    Table 13. PI3Kδ Inhibitors with Indazole Hinge Binding Groups and Related Compounds
      fold selectivity 
    compdPI3Kδ IC50 (nM)α/δβ/δγ/δcell IC50 (nM)
    100.133900013000500000.2a
    110.086300790063000.6a
    741001006363 
    758400630310013a
    76160256350250a
    771    
    784.5320120>2200 
    a

    Human whole blood.

    Surprisingly, until very recently there had not been any reports where others have attempted to take advantage of this motif; however in 2018 Astellas described a series with a pyrazolopyridine hinge binder that also exhibited good isoform selectivity (78).(144)

    Pyrimidine/Quinoxaline Hinge-Binders

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Novartis described the conversion of a nonselective PI3K and mTOR inhibitor (79) to a PI3Kδ inhibitor (80);(145) compounds were unusual in that the hinge-binding motif contained only an aromatic nitrogen as hydrogen bond acceptor and no donor. This series was modified by side chain simplification to improve physicochemical properties (81).(146) Further optimization involving a scaffold hop that increased f(sp3) gave two new series represented by 82(147) and the clinical candidate (12).(148) Interestingly in selecting 12 the team sacrificed some of the isoform selectivity in order to achieve suitable properties for oral dosing. Compound 12 is advancing in development despite a poorer isoform selectivity profile than many other PI3Kδ inhibitors (Table 14).
    Table 14. Quinoline, Quinazoline, and Related Inhibitors
       fold selectivity 
    compdoriginatorPI3Kδ IC50 (nM)α/δβ/δγ/δcell IC50 (nM)
    12Novartis11223820056a
    79Novartis250.77.713 
    80Novartis9291805109a
    81Novartis5777220079a
    82Novartis336   
    83Cadila22    
    84Xi’an Jiantong University2.79.59864 
    85Xi’an Jiantong University31211034 
    a

    Rat-1 cells.

    Cadila has claimed a structurally related series of PI3K inhibitors (83)(149) for which only PI3Kδ inhibition data are reported.
    A group from Xi’an Jiaotong University has published a patent and three papers on quinazoline based inhibitors(150−153) with good potency but only modest selectivity against PI3Kα; two representative examples (84, 85) are shown.

    Aminopyrrolotriazine Hinge Binding Groups

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Bristol-Myers Squibb has described its medicinal chemistry program targeting PI3Kδ inhibitors in a series of papers (Table 15). Their starting point, 86, was a potent but nonselective PI3K inhibitor (broader kinase inhibitory potency and a potent CYP inhibitor).(154) Replacement of the pyridyl group with meta substituted phenyl analogues removed the CYP liability and improved PI3K and general kinase selectivity, while replacement of the cyclohexyl group with 4-pyranyl improved both isoform selectivity and physical properties, resulting in the preferred compound 87. Efficacy was shown in an in vivo model at 30 mg/kg.(154) Toxicity issues enforced further optimization which was guided by structural information. The group targeted the open face of Trp760 of PI3Kδ through increasing the size of the meta substituent, leading to acyl piperazine 88(155) that was active at 3 mg/kg orally in vivo. Further optimization of the scaffold to improve selectivity and permeability began with attempts to reduce PSA that ultimately identified that the pyrazole moiety could be replaced with a halogen or trifluoromethyl group without a detrimental effect on the PI3Kδ potency but gave improved selectivity against PI3Kγ coupled with greatly improved permeability. These small groups did not exhibit inhibition of the hERG channel as was seen for larger lipophilic groups. Further optimization by addition of a group in the 4-position of the phenyl ring improved metabolic stability and potency. The heterocyclic substituent on the phenyl ring was optimized to either a highly selective morpholinone 89,(156) though this turned out to have poor metabolic stability, or an acetylpiperazinone 90,(157) with methyl substitutions to control metabolism and influence potency. Compound 90 was evaluated in a mouse arthritis model and gave an ED50 of 1.25 mg/kg; 90 appears to be the most advanced candidate disclosed but has not been reported to have entered clinical development.
    Table 15. Bristol-Myers Squibb PI3Kδ Inhibitors
      fold selectivity 
    compdPI3Kδ IC50 (nM)α/δβ/δγ/δcell IC50 (nM)
    862241200.4 
    8726708001306a
    881.361014004450a
    890.2>1000>1000>10007b
    901.7700>10010035b
    a

    Human B-cells.

    b

    Human whole blood.

    Morpholine Hinge Binders

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    The use of a morpholine as an H-bond acceptor in the hinge-binding motif was a common feature in several early PI3Kδ inhibitor series going back to the early promiscuous pan-PI3K inhibitor tool compound LY294002 (91 (Figure 10); IC50 PI3Kα 720 nM; β 306 nM; γ 7260 nM; δ 1330 nM (158)). Since 2012, there has been less emphasis on this structural class, though patents and papers have continued to appear with both monocyclic and bicyclic cores (Tables 16 and 17). A Perspective has been published on morpholine-based inhibitors of PI3K and related kinases.(159)
    Table 16. PI3Kδ Inhibitors with Morpholine Hinge Binding Groups and a Monocyclic Core
       fold selectivity 
    compdoriginatorPI3Kδ IC50 (nM)α/δβ/δγ/δcell IC50 (nM)
    6(165,169)MEI8.42200a30a2300.9b

    93Pathway<100>5>2 to >5>5 
    94Pathway<100>5   
    95Pathway<100>5a>5>5 
    96Monash University2617070210

    Cellular selectivity.

    b

    Raji cells.

    Table 17. PI3Kδ Inhibitors with Morpholine Hinge Binding Groups and a Bicyclic Core

    98Piramed/Roche    8300a
    99Roche31112546a
