    Monocyclic Cores

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Astellas has claimed PI3Kδ inhibitors with a monocyclic pyrimidine core and a morpholine hinge with impressive selectivity against PI3Kα.(160) Very recently, an apparent lead compound from this series, AS2541019, has been disclosed (92).(161)
    Three somewhat similar patents with a 1,3,5-triazine monocyclic core and a morpholine hinge appeared from Pathway in 2012 (93, 94, 95).(162−164) A further patent from MEI, who licensed the rights to 6 from Pathway, claimed a single compound along similar lines in 2014;(165) this is likely to be the development compound, though an official declaration has not been made.
    A group from Monash University has investigated structurally related triazines and probed the factors that drive isoform selectivity.(166) By targeting Asp832 and Ans 836 (PI3Kδ) with a pendant amide that was designed to form a charge interaction or hydrogen bond, they were able to increase δ-selectivity; experiments with mutated analogues of PI3Kδ confirmed the involvement of the targeted residues. A related patent describes some more examples, the best of which exhibits further enhanced selectivity (96).(167)
    Takeda have claimed a series of structurally related compounds carrying a morpholine attached to a pyrimidine but fused via an additional ring to give a series of tricycles (97).(168) They reported excellent potencies at PI3Kδ, but no data were given for the other isoforms.

    Bicyclic Cores

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Genentech/Roche have published several papers on their collaborations with Piramed and Argenta. Although the order of their discoveries is not clear, it appears that they started from a series discovered at Piramed based on a thienopyrimidine core 98(170) with pan-PI3K inhibitory activity (PI3Kα IC50 = 100 nM). This core was optimized to the pan-PI3K inhibitor 99.(170) Variation of substituents gave selectivity in favor of PI3Kδ; scaffold-hopping to a pyridopyrimidine core and further changes of substituents gave >200-fold selectivity against all other isoforms leading to compound 100.(171) Unfortunately, this molecule exhibited time-dependent CYP inhibition.(172) An alternative scaffold-hop to a purine core, however, gave, after reoptimization of substituents, new leads 101, 102(173) without the CYP liabilities. More detailed profiling revealed that 102 exhibited an Ames liability, requiring a further cycle of modifications to give a highly selective compound 103 without Ames issues.(174) A further compound from the same series appears to have been investigated extensively but turned out to have bioavailability issues relating to low solubility 104.(175) None of these compounds have yet entered human trials.
    Two patents have since appeared from Shanghai Xingli using the same thienopyrimidine 105(176) and purine cores 106(177) albeit with a different arrangement of the substituents.
    Further bicyclic cores such as isoxazolopyrimidines (Jilin, 107),(178) imidazopyridine (Daiichi, 108),(179) and pyrazolopyrimidine (Celon, 109)(180) have also been reported.

    6,8,9 Trisubstituted Purines

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Exelixis claimed a series of PI3Kδ inhibitors based on a purine core substituted at the 6, 8, and 9 positions (110).(181) This series was licensed by Merck (Table 18). The first two Merck patents then differed principally in the heteroatom linking to the 6-substituent (111, 112).(182,183) These compounds were clearly very potent inhibitors with subnanomolar IC50 values against PI3Kδ, but selectivity was only claimed as >10-fold. Further patents in 2015 (113),(184) 2016 (114),(185) and 2017 (115, 116)(186,187) showed additional variations; however isoform selectivity is still reported as >10-fold. Whether any compound with sufficient selectivity coupled with suitable PK properties for development has been identified is as yet unclear.
    Table 18. Exelixis and Merck PI3Kδ Inhibitorsa
       fold selectivity
    compdoriginatorPI3Kδ IC50 (nM)α/δβ/δγ/δ
    110Exelixis7.5(188)>13>13>13
    111Merck<1>10  
    112Merck<1>10  
    113Merck<1>10  
    114Merck<1>10  
    115Merck2.8>10  
    116Merck0.7>10  
    a

    The asterisk ∗ in the above table section containing drawn chemical structures indicates undefined absolute stereochemistry.

    Other Hinge Binding Groups

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    A group from the Chinese Academy of Sciences in Heifei has claimed a series of PI3Kδ inhibitors based on an aminothiazole hinge binding group (117)(189) (Table 19). The best of these compounds shows modest selectivity against the other isoforms. A recent AstraZeneca patent discloses a series of dual PI3Kγδ inhibitors that also feature a thiazole hinge binding group (118).(190)
    Table 19. Other PI3Kδ Inhibitors
       fold selectivity 
    compdoriginatorPI3Kδ IC50 (nM)α/δβ/δγ/δcell IC50 (nM)
    117Heifei0.6173571 
    118AstraZeneca0.77819001.3 
    119DanaFarber22824003.51400a
    120AstraZeneca0.85000200002000120b
    121Genentech1.9110   
    a

    Jurkat.

    b

    JeKo1.

    An aminopyrimidine is used as the hinge binding group in a series of tricyclic dual PI3Kγδ inhibitors from the Dana Farber Institute (119).(191) These molecules show good selectivity against PI3Kβ but modest selectivity against PI3Kα; some members of the class further show activity against Aurora kinases.
    AstraZeneca has reported another series that were derived from a PI3Kα series using an aminopyrazine (120) as the hinge binding group.(192) These compounds were highly selective for PI3Kδ in enzyme assays but had weaker cell activities.
    A combined Genentech–Charles River group has reported a series derived by chemical modification of a PI3Kα selective benzoxazepin starting point. This involved replacement of an amide, designed to interact with Glu-859 (PI3Kα numbering) that is specific to PI3Kα, with a piperazine designed to occupy the tryptophan shelf.(193) Potency was optimized through addition of an α-methyl group to control the conformation of the piperazine, while metabolic stability was controlled by modulation of lipophilicity, leading to the identification of 121.

    Kinase Selectivity of Nonpropeller PI3Kδ Inhibitors

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Selectivity against panels of kinases has been reported for a variety of nonpropeller PI3Kδ inhibitors (Table 20). As with the propeller-shaped inhibitors discussed above (Table 12), selectivity is generally excellent, with at least 100-fold margin over all other kinases tested in every case. The kinases that are inhibited by these compounds show no obvious pattern with only one kinase, the related class III PI3K, Vps34, being inhibited by two molecules.
    Table 20. Selectivity Profiles for Nonpropeller-Shaped PI3Kδ Inhibitors
    compdno. of kinases screened (concn)kinase hits
    6(169)∼450 kinases (1 μM) “no activity against unrelated kinases” 
    10(140)>250, all >1000-fold selectivity 
    11(140)>250, all >100-fold selectivity 
    12(148)442 protein and lipid kinases (10 μM)DNAPK IC50 = 0.88 μM; RPS6KA5 76% at 10 μM
    75(141)140 protein kinases, 10 lipid kinases (1 μM)Vps34 IC50 = 0.063 μM
    80(145)40 protein kinases, 3 lipid kinases (10 μM)Vps34 IC50 = 4.1 μM
    89(156)All tested kinases >100-fold selectivity 
    90(157)253 kinases, all >660-fold selectivity 
    92(161)29 kinases (10 μM), maximum 34% inhibition 
    101(173)55 kinases (1 μM), <25% inhibition 
    102(173)55 kinases (1 μM), <25% inhibition 
    103(174)239 kinases (1 μM), B-Raf 61% and PI4Kb 71% inhibition 
    119(191)Full kinome scan (1 μM), 8 kinases inhibited >50%Aurora A 0.15 μM, Aurora B 0.15 μM
    120(192)350 kinases (1 μM), 5 inhibited >50%DYRK1A IC50 = 0.14 μM, DYRK1B IC50 = 0.33 μM, CSNK1G3 IC50 = 0.46 μM

    Selective PI3Kγ Inhibitors

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    PI3Kγ selective compounds are of great interest for inflammation and autoimmune diseases. Lately their potential in immuno-oncology applications and for the treatment of cardiovascular diseases has further increased the interest. Development of isoform selective PI3Kγ inhibitors has been difficult given the high sequence similarity between the isoforms. From a safety perspective, a high isoform selectivity is required, especially toward PI3Kα, which has been shown to affect glucose and insulin signaling,(194) while PI3Kβ inhibition has been shown to cause thrombus instability and increase the shedding of platelet emboli.(195) Furthermore, PI3Kα and β are ubiquitously expressed and genetic inactivation of PI3Kα or β results in embryonic lethality in mice.(196,197) Compounds with good isoform and wider kinase selectivity are highly desirable in order to develop drug candidates with sufficient therapeutic index, especially for non-life-threatening indications, and also for use as pharmacological tools to further investigate the biological role of PI3Ks. Several promising selective inhibitors have been disclosed since 2012 that are potentially opening further therapeutic applications (Table 21).
    Table 21. Examples of PI3Kγ Inhibitors from Literature and Patentsa
       fold selectivity 
    compdoriginatorPI3Kγ IC50 (nM)α/γβ/γδ/γcell IC50 (nM)
    14Infinity16200220>530180e
    122Cellzome13502020500c
    123Cellzome2540050317 
    124Pfizer1901.55.06.567d
    125Pfizer695.61113170d
    126Pfizer1105.92617140d
    127Taisho35  110e
    128Taisho29   290e
    129Sha567>185 
    130Temple University100025000850026000150f
    131Novartis3639139270g
    132Novartis158739067500h
    133Vertex266216183i
    134Vertex315058120180i
    135Vertex8302619240i
    136Vertex4601014170i
    137Incyte<50    
    138Incyte<100<500b  <100i
    139AstraZeneca17800>330003508
    a

    The asterisk ∗ in the above table section containing drawn chemical structures indicates undefined absolute stereochemistry.

    b

    IC50 (nM).

    c

    Neutrophil migration.

    d

    Neutrophil shape in human lysed blood.

    e

    RAW 264 murine macrophages.

    f

    K562 cells.

    g

    fMLP stimulated human neutrophil assay.

    h

    Whole blood neutrophil shape change.

    i

    THP-1 cells.

    Cellzome disclosed 122 that was suitable for oral dosing and showed promising 50-fold selectivity toward PI3Kα and good pan kinase selectivity.(198) The margins toward β and δ were somewhat lower (20-fold). Another close analogue, 123, was reported to have significantly improved isoform selectivity (400-fold toward PI3Kα) but exhibited poor thermodynamic solubility that limited the preclinical development.(199) Pfizer published three lead series that were optimized to give 124, 125, and 126.(200) These were not further pursued since the combination of a suitable pharmacokinetic profile with adequate isoform selectivity could not be achieved.
    Taisho discovered compound 127 that displayed high potency against PI3Kγ (3 nM), but the compound still displayed poor selectivity against PI3Kα (15 nM).(201) The deacetylated analogue was positive in an Ames test, and further optimization was undertaken to yield 128 that was Ames negative and demonstrated oral in vivo efficacy in a collagen-induced arthritis (CIA) mouse model. Selectivity against the other isoforms was not reported.(202) Sha et al. published fluoroquinolone derivatives as selective and potent PI3Kγ inhibitors, exemplified by compound 129 having improved potency; 129 showed >18-fold selectivity against PI3Kβ but only 6.5-fold selectivity against PI3Kα.(203)
    A group from Temple University published a patent which was exemplified by 130 with a modest potency for PI3Kγ and >8.5-fold selectivity against the other isoforms (25-fold selectivity against PI3Kα).(204)
    An article from Novartis describes the optimization of a pan PI3K HTS hit to increase isoform selectivity. Improved PI3Kγ selectivity could be obtained by extending the urea moiety to the hydrophobic binding cleft at the outer part of the binding site to provide compound 131 that displayed a 39-fold selectivity toward PI3Kα and >9-fold selectivity against PI3Kβ and PI3Kδ, respectively.(205) A subsequent patent from Novartis exemplifies compounds with improved selectivity; for example, 132 exhibited 86-fold selectivity toward PI3Kα.(206)
    Vertex further explored this hydrophobic binding. By taking advantage of the isoform sequence differences, an improved isoform selectivity could be obtained to provide urea containing compound, 133, having 66-fold selectivity over PI3Kα.(207) Further optimization led to inhibitors with yet higher levels of selectivity, such as 134, that displayed 150-fold selectivity over PI3Kα as well as good selectivity against the other isoforms.(208) In addition, 134 was selective in a pan kinase panel containing 65 kinases at 2 μM. Vertex claimed a series containing a pyridopyrrolidinone core exemplified by 135 that shows good potency toward PI3Kγ and 30-fold selectivity over PI3Kα.(209) The preferred compound 135 has been reported to show good toxicology margins and in vivo efficacy in mouse models for pancreas, colon, lymphoma, and bladder cancers to support progression into clinical evaluations; however no clinical trials have been reported yet.(209) The series was further optimized to yield 136 that had improved CNS exposure in order to explore the potential for the treatment of multiple sclerosis.(210)
    Incyte published two patents claiming PI3Kγ inhibitors in 2017; in the first patent, 137 showed modest selectivity against δ and poor cell potency.(211) In the second patent, 138 showed increased activity toward γ which was also reflected in cell.(212) Selectivity data toward PI3Kα and β were not disclosed however.
    Infinity published a remarkable selectivity profile for the clinical candidate 14.(56) The compound was very potent against PI3Kγ (16 nM) and had 200-fold selectivity against PI3Kα in biochemical assays. The high level of selectivity was achieved by taking advantage of isoform sequence differences around the selectivity pocket. As discussed above, “propeller” shaped inhibitors are normally PI3Kδ selective or dual PI3Kγδ selective. For this group of compounds the selectivity was altered by use of a modified hinge binding group that subtly modified the orientation of the core, which, coupled with the pyrazolylalkyne on the isoquinolinone moiety, exploited differences between PI3Kγ and δ on the periphery of the binding site, resulting in a switch from the normal PI3Kδ selectivity for this chemotype to PI3Kγ.
    AstraZeneca recently described compounds with an alternative binding mode and with high isoform selectivity.(213) The potent compound 139 had ADME properties suitable for oral administration and showed >7800-fold selectivity against PI3Kα as well as excellent pan kinase selectivity. In addition, the compound also displayed 8 nM cellular potency and efficacy could be demonstrated in vivo. This series has been further expanded to yield dual PI3Kγ/δ selective compounds such as 118.(190)

    Structural Determinants Driving Selectivity toward PI3Kγ or δ

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Considerable understanding has been gained regarding structural determinants driving selectivity toward PI3Kγ and δ. Four distinct regions in the active site have been identified: (1) the selectivity pocket, (2) the tryptophan shelf, (3) the hydrophobic cleft next to the ATP binding site, and (4) the alkyl push around the DFG motif and the Kα3 helix (Figures 11–14).
    Berndt et al. showed that the propeller class of PI3Kδ inhibitors induces a pocket around Trp760 and Met752 (selectivity pocket) exploring dynamic differences between isoforms in the P-Loop (Figure 11).(83) They further claimed that extending into the affinity pocket and interacting with the hydrogen bond network can lead to increased activity at PI3Kδ and, in some cases, PI3Kγ as well (17 but compare 2, 18, 60 to 15, 16) sometimes producing dual PI3Kγδ activity.
    Genentech described the steric differences between PI3Kδ and the other three PI3K class 1 isoforms at Trp760 (the so-called tryptophan shelf, Figure 12) as a means to obtain isoform selectivity;(171) they showed that the residue corresponding to Thr750 in PI3Kδ is in PI3Kα, β, and γ an Arg, Lys, and Lys, respectively, and that these residues occlude the face of the tryptophan, resulting in steric blockage. Compounds that occupy this region have disfavored binding to PI3Kα, β and γ. They exploited this in the synthesis of selective inhibitors like 100. This selectivity feature is also used by some other nonpropeller inhibitors to obtain selectivity for PI3Kδ (10, 11, 120).
    It has proven considerably more challenging to obtain PI3Kγ selective inhibitors. Collier et al. showed that they could gain selectivity by targeting a hydrophobic cleft adjacent to the ATP binding pocket (Figure 13).(207)Here differences in the hinge region were explored where the residue corresponding to Ala885 in PI3Kγ is a serine in PI3Kα, β, and δ, believed to cause steric hindrance. Additionally, Gly829 in PI3Kγ corresponds to Glu in PI3Kα, enhancing the selectivity over PI3Kα.
    Recently a new class of inhibitors have been described that bind deep in the conserved ATP binding pocket.(213) This class of inhibitors achieve their selectivity by introducing a branched alkyl group that induces a pocket within the affinity pocket by a so-called “alkyl push” leading to conformational changes around the DFG motif and the Kα3 helix (equivalent to the α-C helix in a protein kinase; Figure 13). These inhibitors have reached up to 1000-fold selectivity over PI3Kα, β, and δ; the selectivity has been explained as a consequence of greater flexibility of the PI3Kγ protein as compared to the other isoforms.

    Evaluations of PI3K Inhibitors in in Vivo Models

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    A number of industrial groups have published their lead compounds and described experimental animal studies in inflammatory and immunological models. Additional studies have been carried out in the academic community using some of these optimized compounds.
    Initial studies have shown effects on B-cell activation or production of cytokines or antibodies in vivo. Using the inhibition of CD86 expression on B-cells in response to IgD stimulation, oral dosing of 102 achieved a pharmacological effect at doses of 1 mg/kg and greater.(173) The PI3Kδ inhibitor 3 and related compounds were shown to have a dose-dependent effect on IgM and IgG production in a keyhole limpet hemocyanin (KLH) induced inflammatory model, where the response is antibody production from B-cells in a T-cell dependent manner.(91) Compound 3 itself was active at doses between 0.3 and 3 mg/kg/day po. The same KLH model was used to show in vivo efficacy of PI3Kδ inhibitors 88(155) and 90.(157) In the same study, 90 also inhibited a T-cell independent IgM antibody production using stimulation with TNP-Ficoll. Compound 12 was active in an assay measuring the reduction of IgM production in rats after inoculation with sheep red blood cells.(148)
    Inhibition of IL2 cytokine production in vivo was shown for the PI3Kδ inhibitors 13(92) (po doses of 1 mg/kg and greater essentially abolished IL-2 production), 1(100) (ID50 = 1.6 mg/kg po), and 25(100) (ID50 = 0.13 mg/kg po).
    PI3Kγ inhibitors 14(56) and 122(198) showed inhibition of neutrophil migration in murine air-pouch models. A similar experiment in rats was used for the dual PI3Kγδ inhibitor 15,(88) while a PI3Kδ inhibitor was inactive in this model, confirming the PI3Kγ drive.

    Arthritis

    In vivo models of arthritis, such as collagen-induced arthritis (CIA), have been widely used for PI3Kγ, PI3Kδ, and PI3Kγδ inhibitors, with both isoforms contributing to efficacy (Table 22).
    Table 22. CIA Experiments with PI3K Inhibitors
    compdspeciesdosing route and frequencydose range (mg/kg)ED50a (mg/kg)other outcome measuresa
    8(84)ratpo, b.i.d.0.3–30.6–2.3 
    12(148)ratpo, b.i.d.3 and 10 (prophylactic) Prophylactic: full inhibition at both doses
       10 (therapeutic) Therapeutic: markedly significant reduction in disease severity
    15(88)ratpo, q.d.0.1–10 Swelling reduced 0.5 mg/kg and higher
         Effects on histopathology from 0.1 mg/kg
         Additional benefit at 10 mg/kg ascribed to inhibition of PI3Kγ and PI3Kδ
    15(214)mousepo, q.d.10 and 50 (prophylactic) Prophylactic treatment effective at both doses; therapeutic treatment ineffective
       50 (therapeutic) 
    59(119)ratpo, b.i.d.0.34–101.5 
    87(154)mousepo, b.i.d.30 and 100 Significant inhibition at both doses, almost complete at top dose
    90(157)mousepo, b.i.d.0.5–51.25 
    123(198)mousepo, b.i.d3 and 10 42% inhibition at 10 mg/kg
    128(202)mousepo, b.i.d.10–100 Significant inhibition at 30 and 100 mg/kg
    a

    All studies evaluated joint swelling and histopathological outcomes.

    The most detailed report(214) studied the effects of 15 on MMP-3 and 13 mRNA production, which were reduced, as were autoantibodies to type II collagen. Effects were also seen on immunoglobulin class switching with lower ratios of IgG2a and, at the highest dose, higher levels of serum IgE suggesting reduced switching to IgG. The same paper also reported a study using 15 in an adjuvant arthritis model in rats, dosing at 50 mg/kg both prophylactically and therapeutically; significant effects were seen for all measured criteria with prophylactic dosing; therapeutic dosing showed an effect on swelling but no significant effects on histopathology or radiographic measures.

    Asthma and COPD

    The main model used with PI3K inhibitors for asthma has been a rat or mouse ovalbumin model with the primary readout migration of inflammatory cells to the lung as measured in bronchio-alveolar lavage (BAL). Alternatively, transgenic OTII mice were dosed with anti-CD3 intranasally, and inhibition of the phosphorylation of phospho S6 ribosomal protein (S6RP), a biomarker for PI3Kδ inhibition, was measured. A similar model, LPS induced neutrophilia, a COPD directed model, has been used with PI3Kγ inhibitors. Outcomes are shown in Table 23.
    Table 23. PI3K Inhibitors in Models of Lung Inflammation
    compdmodeldose range (mg/kg) and routeoutcomecomments
    10(140)Rat OVA0.028–0.69 i.t.ED50 = 67 μg/kg for eosinophil recruitmentMultiple leukocytes and cytokines dose-dependently reduced
    11(140)Rat OVAi.t.ED50 = 35 μg/kg for eosinophil recruitment 
    15(88)Rat OVA0.1–10 q.d., poSignificant reduction in eosinophils in BAL at 1 and 10 mg/kg10 mg/kg dose also showed lower cytokine levels in BAL and fewer inflammatory lesions
    17(86)Mouse OVA1 μg and 4 μg/animal i.n.Eosinophil (25%, 62%) and neutrophil (21%, 56%) influx reduced 
    18(87)Mouse OVA1, 4, 20 μg/animal i.t.aEosinophil (20%, 85%, 91%) and neutrophil (18%, 70%, 80%) influx reduced 
    18(87)Mouse LPS1, 4, 20 μg/animal i.t.Neutrophil numbers in BAL reduced (19%, 53%, 68%) at 2 h postdoseTime-course experiment (4 μg/animal) gave 45% inhibition at 8 h and 23% at 12 h
    18(87)Rat LPS5, 20, 100 μg/animal i.t.Neutrophil numbers in BAL reduced (9%, 58%, 73%) at 2 h postdoseTime-course experiment (20 μg/animal) gave 33% inhibition at 8 h and 10% at 12 h
    25(100)Rat OVA0.1–3 b.i.d., poED50 = 0.16 mg/kg for eosinophil accumulation 
    33(108)OTII mouse0.15–1.5 mg/kg i.t.Inhibition of pS6RP at 0.15 and 1.5 mg/kg 
    76(142)Rat OVA3 and 9 mg/kg poInhibition of eosinophil migration at 3 mg/kg 
    124(200)Rat LPS0.1–3000 mg/kg poInhibition of neutrophilia EC50 = 1.3 μM17-fold margin over insulin elevation
    125(200)Rat LPS0.1–3000 mg/kg poInhibition of neutrophilia EC50 = 0.26 μM13-fold margin over insulin elevation
    126(200)Rat LPS0.1–3000 mg/kg poInhibition of neutrophilia EC50 = 3.2 μM1.9-fold margin over insulin elevation
    139(213)Rat LPS0.1–2.5 mg/kg poAll doses significant and >50% inhibition of neutrophil migration 
    a

    Volume administered not defined but assumed to be the same as mouse LPS study.

    In addition to the ovalbumin study reported above Respivert describe two additional models where inhibition of cell accumulation in mouse lung airways was investigated.(86,87) In the first model mice were challenged with poly-I:C; influx of both macrophages and neutrophils was shown to be inhibited with an IC50 of approximately 7 μg/animal i.n. for 17 and 0.8 μg/animal i.n. for 18. The second model involved inhibition of cigarette-smoke-induced cell accumulation in murine BAL; an IC50 of about 7 μg/animal (inhibition of both macrophages and neutrophils) was achieved with 17, while 18 appeared to be somewhat less effective (63% and 54% inhibition at 70 μg/animal). If, however, fluticasone propionate (1.75 μg/animal) was co-dosed with 17, the effects were much greater with 60% inhibition of both macrophages and neutrophils achieved at a dose of 0.7 μg/animal, even though fluticasone alone at this concentration was ineffective as a monotherapy. A similar claim is made for 18, but the data presented do not show any difference in the presence of fluticasone.

    Organ Transplantation

    In an extensive study, Uehara et al.(133) investigated the roles of PI3Kγ and δ inhibition through both knock-out/inactive knock-in mice models plus studies using a PI3Kδ inhibitor (72) and a relatively balanced PI3Kγδ dual inhibitor (143; enzyme IC50 PI3Kα 3000 nM, β 18000 nM, γ 800 nM, δ 600 nM; Figure 15). In a mouse heart allograft survival model, treatment with 61 (50 mg/kg, po, b.i.d.) extended allograft survival from a mean of 7 days to 13.5 days. The dual inhibitor 132 (100 mg/kg, po, q.d.) had a significantly greater effect (mean survival time 35 days). Addition of multiple doses of a CTLA4 antibody to treatment with 72 increased survival to a mean of 91 days in wild-type animals. In PI3Kγ KO animals, even a single dose of antibody in combination with 72 ensured that all transplants survived for >100 days.
    A hamster to rat xenotransplantation model was used to assess the effectiveness of PI3Kδ inhibition using 90 (1, 2, or 4 mg/kg po) in addition to tacrolimus and mycophenolate mofetil.(161) Statistically significant reductions in IgM after 7 days (all doses), in IgG1/2a after 14 days (only 2 and 4 mg/kg), and in the prolongation of graft survival (dose-proportional, all doses) were observed.

    Lupus

    A mouse model of systemic lupus erythematosus nephritis was used to study the effects of PI3Kγ and δ inhibition on kidney damage using 15.(88) Over a 20-week period doses of 5 and 10 mg/kg po, q.d. gave significant reductions in the levels of anti dsDNA antibodies in plasma. Proteinuria, however, was significantly reduced not only at these doses but also at a lower dose of 1 mg/kg. Histopathological assessments at termination showed dose-dependent significant reductions in the levels of glomerulonephritis, kidney vessels, and protein casts at all doses and for interstitial nephritis at 5 and 10 mg/kg.

    Multiple Sclerosis

    The CNS-penetrant PI3Kγ inhibitor 136 was evaluated in a murine EAE model of multiple sclerosis.(210) Significant reduction in clinical scores was obtained at doses of 3, 10, and 30 mg/kg po, b.i.d., and good exposure in brain with levels reaching or exceeding the functional IC50 was shown. The older PI3Kγ inhibitor 144 (PI3Kγ IC50 = 0.25 μM; Figure 15) has also been tested in the same EAE model(215) with subcutaneous dosing (7.5 mg/kg q.d. for 7 or 14 days; higher doses proved fatal). Symptoms were significantly reduced, and histopathological investigation revealed enhanced myelination and axon numbers in the spinal cord.

    Sjögren’s Syndrome

    The involvement of PI3Kδ in the salivary glands of Sjögren’s syndrome patients but not those with nonspecific chronic sialoadenitis was established by histological staining for the downstream marker pS6. Following this, a mouse model of ectopic lymphoneogenesis was used to show that inhibition of PI3Kδ with compound 13 (po) resolved the inflammation through reduction of the influx of T and B cells.(216)

    Summary

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    PI3Kγ and δ inhibition has progressed significantly since 2012. The first PI3Kδ inhibitor, 1, is now established in clinical use in leukemia and lymphoma, although in a relatively restricted role in part because of the restrictive label and black-box warning that limits wider use.
    The dual PI3Kγδ inhibitor 15 showed some efficacy in a clinical trial of allergic challenge in asthmatic patients but was not effective at a lower dose against RA and has not been further developed in any nononcology indications. Compound 15 has continued development for leukemias and lymphomas at higher doses that appear not to be acceptable for asthma and RA. Compound 15 is expected to be launched soon. As with 1, toxicity concerns may limit the take-up of the drug.
    Similar patterns of toxicity have been reported for other PI3Kδ and γδ inhibitors; it will be interesting to see if the compounds targeting nononcologic applications are sufficiently safe in clinical practice. The most advanced of these compounds appears to be 10, which is both highly isoform selective and dosed via inhalation, thereby potentially minimizing systemic exposure and undesired side effects.
    The biological understanding of the roles of PI3Kγ and δ in inflammatory processes has increased significantly, in part aided by the development of more isoform selective inhibitors allowing greater precision in the dissection of biological effects. The two isoforms have a complex interrelationship in cells of the immune system, with each isoform playing an important role. The risk/benefit equation between degree of inhibition and undesired mechanism-related side effects, such as the increased risk of infection observed with 1 and 15 in clinical trials, will be a key factor in the success or failure of this class of compounds. This risk comes on top of the risks associated with off-target activity.
    The medicinal chemistry of PI3Kδ inhibition is still dominated by the propeller-shaped type of molecules with ever-increasing numbers of scaffolds being disclosed. Isoform selectivity in this class is subtle, with marked variations between pure PI3Kδ and dual PI3Kγδ inhibition; the choice of substituents, particularly in the affinity pocket and extending from the “5-position”, appears to be the most relevant factor. Levels of PI3Kβ inhibition vary; here interaction with Asp856 (PI3Kβ) appears to be significant. Selectivity against PI3Kα is typically good in this series. Of the nonpropeller PI3Kδ inhibitors 10 continues to advance in clinical trials; with high isoform selectivity and inhaled administration 10 has a promising future. The other two nonpropeller compounds in development, 6 and 12, are both less selective against one or two of the other isoforms. It remains to be seen how this will affect tolerability in patients; to date, only a single study for 6 has been reported. The compound is only developed for cancer. Other nonpropeller classes have been extensively worked on and patented during the past 6 years; however, isoform selectivity has been a challenge, and this may be a block to further progress.
    The field of PI3Kγ inhibition has been revolutionized in the past few years with some genuinely selective molecules; in spite of this, much of the biological validation of the target has used tool compounds of questionable selectivity. The difficulty of obtaining isoform selectivity was highlighted by a publication detailing extensive optimization of a series that ultimately yielded only modest selectivity for PI3Kγ (136, 60-, 10-, 14-fold, respectively, against PI3Kα, β, δ (210)). The trailblazer compound 14 provided the first truly isoform selective PI3Kγ inhibitor with greater than 200-fold selectivity against the other three isoforms and is progressing in clinical trials in the oncology setting.(81) An even more selective PI3Kγ inhibitor (139) has been disclosed recently with 350-fold selectivity against PI3Kδ and greater than 1000-fold against PI3Kα and β.(199) These two latter compounds provide greatly improved tools for study of the role of the PI3Kγ isoform in inflammatory models and disease.
    PI3Kγδ dual inhibition has potential to provide a broader effect than inhibition of either single isoform alone;(217) however the challenges of selectivity are at least as great as for a compound targeting a single isoform and are on top of the difficulty of balancing activity at two isoforms with all the other requirements for any compound to become a drug. Any undesired mechanism-based side effects from inhibition of either isoform will be a potential issue. How many genuinely dual inhibitors have been identified remains to be seen, as it is often not clear from patents what the actual balance of selectivity is. Few papers provide details of biological or clinical studies using dual inhibitors,(58,88,214) mostly using 15 as the inhibitor. Direct evidence for an advantage of dual inhibition over a single isoform is extremely limited.(218) The field of dual inhibition thus represents an area that remains significantly open for further work.
    Despite the progress made in developing inhibitors of PI3Kγ and δ, the limitations of the current most advanced compounds mean that the full potential of this class of drugs is yet to be revealed, particularly for inflammatory conditions. Whether it will be possible for a safe and effective PI3Kγ, or δ, let alone γδ, inhibitor to be launched for widespread use in inflammatory conditions remains an open question.

      • Barbara Valastro - Respiratory, Inflammation & Autoimmunity Translational Medicine Unit, Early Clinical Development, , , and , AstraZeneca Gothenburg, Mölndal SE-431 83, Sweden

    • Author Contributions

    1. 1
      Cushing, T. D.; Metz, D. P.; Whittington, D. A.; McGee, L. R. PI3Kδ and PI3Kγ as Targets for Autoimmune and Inflammatory Diseases. J. Med. Chem. 2012, 55 (20), 8559– 8581,  DOI: 10.1021/jm300847w
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      1
      PI3Kδ and PI3Kγ as Targets for Autoimmune and Inflammatory Diseases
      Cushing, Timothy D.; Metz, Daniela P.; Whittington, Douglas A.; McGee, Lawrence R.
      Journal of Medicinal Chemistry (2012), 55 (20), 8559-8581CODEN: JMCMAR; ISSN:0022-2623. (American Chemical Society)
      A review. Targeting signaling mols. that are required for the activation of multiple immune cells may be a more likely route to success in combating chronic, immune cell-mediated diseases (such as rheumatoid arthritis, systemic lupus erythematosus, and asthma). This review will highlight two such signaling mols., the related lipid kinases, class I PI3K (phosphoinositide 3-kinase) δ and γ, both of which are primarily expressed in leukocytes and seem to play important roles in their function and activation. This review will compare and contrast these two kinases as targets for autoimmune and inflammatory diseases and summarize efforts toward the development of small mol. inhibitors of PI3Kδ and PI3Kγ. Phosphoinositides (PIs) act as second messengers in a wide variety of cellular roles including signal transduction, control of membrane trafficking and transport, cytoskeleton organization, cell survival and death, among many other functions. The target of PI3K kinase activity is the phosphoinositides within cell membranes.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38Xht1KjsrjL&md5=76fc05c3bf303174add4aca98f526f8f
    2. 2
      Wymann, M. P.; Pirola, L. Structure and Function of Phosphoinositide 3-Kinases. Biochim. Biophys. Acta, Mol. Cell Biol. Lipids 1998, 1436 (1–2), 127– 150,  DOI: 10.1016/S0005-2760(98)00139-8
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      2
      Structure and function of phosphoinositide 3-kinases
      Wymann, Matthias P.; Pirola, Luciano
      Biochimica et Biophysica Acta, Molecular and Cell Biology of Lipids (1998), 1436 (1-2), 127-150CODEN: BBMLFG; ISSN:1388-1981. (Elsevier B.V.)
      A review with 311 refs. Phosphoinositide kinases (PI3Ks) play an important role in mitogenic signaling and cell survival, cytoskeletal remodeling, metabolic control, and vesicular trafficking. Here, the authors summarize structure-function relations delineating the activation process of class I PI3Ks involving various domains of adapter subunits, Ras, and interacting proteins. The resulting product, phosphatidylinositol (PtdIns) 3,4,5-bisphosphate, targets Akt/protein kinase B (PKB), Bruton's tyrosine kinase (Btk), phosphoinositide-dependent kinases (PDK), integrin-linked kinase (ILK), atypical protein kinases C (PKC), phosphatidylinositol phospholipase Cγ, and more. Surface receptor-activated PI3Ks function in mammals, insects, nematodes, and slime mold, but not yeast. Whereas many members of the class II family have been identified and characterized biochem., it is presently unknown how these C2-domain contg. PI3Ks are activated, and which PI substrate they phosphorylate in vivo. PtdIns 3-phosphate is produced by Vps34p/class III PI3Ks and operates via the PtdIns 3-phosphate-binding proteins, early endosomal antigen (EEA1) and yeast Vac1p, Vps27p, and Pip1p, in lysosomal protein targeting. Besides the prodn. of D3 phosphorylated lipids, PI3Ks have an intrinsic protein kinase activity. For trimeric GTP-binding protein-activated PI3Kγ, protein kinase activity seems to be sufficient to trigger mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK). Recent disruption of PI3K genes in the slime mold, Caenorhabditis elegans, Drosophila melanogaster, and mice further underlines the importance of PI3K signaling systems and elucidates the role of PI3K signaling in multicellular organisms.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK1cXns1Klur8%253D&md5=b93d9a7245d3d09b6a3a938cceedc1c2

      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      3
      Agonist-stimulated synthesis of phosphatidylinositol(3,4,5)-trisphosphate: a new intracellular signalling system?
      Stephens, L. R.; Jackson, T. R.; Hawkins, P. T.
      Biochimica et Biophysica Acta, Molecular Cell Research (1993), 1179 (1), 27-75CODEN: BBAMCO; ISSN:0167-4889. (Elsevier B.V.)
      A review, with 348 refs., of the metab. and functions of the family of membrane phospholipids, the 3-phosphorylated phosphoinositides. The integration of these phosphorylated phosphoinositides in the signal transduction pathways for receptors (e.g. those activated by cytokines, growth factors, small hormones, and antigens) is discussed.

      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK2cXitlKltg%253D%253D&md5=e54e47e570cc96df6b38794dcaabb818

      Cantley, L. C. The Phosphoinositide 3-Kinase Pathway. Science 2002, 296 (5573), 1655– 1657,  DOI: 10.1126/science.296.5573.1655

      4
      The phosphoinositide 3-kinase pathway
      Cantley, Lewis C.
      Science (Washington, DC, United States) (2002), 296 (5573), 1655-1657CODEN: SCIEAS; ISSN:0036-8075. (American Association for the Advancement of Science)
      A review with 8 refs. Phosphorylated lipids are produced at cellular membranes during signaling events and contribute to the recruitment and activation of various signaling components. The role of phosphoinositide 3-kinase (PI3K), which catalyzes the prodn. of phosphatidylinositol 3,4,5-trisphosphate, in cell survival pathways; the regulation of gene expression and cell metab.; and cytoskeletal rearrangements are highlighted. The PI3K pathway is implicated in human diseases including diabetes and cancer, and understanding the intricacies of this pathway may provide new avenues for therapeutic intervention.

      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD38XktlChu7s%253D&md5=110c8a351448aed6ab938b9ccf90a655
    5. 5
      Suire, S.; Coadwell, J.; Ferguson, G. J.; Davidson, K.; Hawkins, P.; Stephens, L. p84, a New Gβγ-Activated Regulatory Subunit of the Type IB Phosphoinositide 3-Kinase p110γ. Curr. Biol. 2005, 15 (6), 566– 570,  DOI: 10.1016/j.cub.2005.02.020
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      5
      p84, a New Gβγ-Activated Regulatory Subunit of the Type IB Phosphoinositide 3-Kinase p110γ
      Suire, Sabine; Coadwell, John; Ferguson, G. John; Davidson, Keith; Hawkins, Phillip; Stephens, Len
      Current Biology (2005), 15 (6), 566-570CODEN: CUBLE2; ISSN:0960-9822. (Cell Press)
      Summary: A variety of genetic and inhibitor studies have shown that phosphoinositide 3-kinase γ (PI3Kγ) plays an essential role in a no. of physiol. responses, including neutrophil chemotaxis, mast cell degranulation, and cardiac function. PI3Kγ is currently thought to be composed of a p110γ catalytic subunit and a single regulatory subunit, p101. The binding of p110γ to p101 dramatically increases the activation of the complex by Gβγ subunits and, hence, is thought to be crit. for the coupling of PI3Kγ to G protein coupled receptors. Here, we characterize a new regulatory subunit for PI3Kγ. P84 is present in human, mouse, chicken, frog, and fugu genomes and is located beside the p101 locus. It is broadly expressed in cells of the murine immune system. Both recombinant and endogenous p84 bind p110γ specifically and with high affinity. Binding of p84 to p110γ substantially increases the ability of Gβγ to stimulate phosphatidylinositol (3,4,5)-trisphosphate (PtdIns(3,4,5)P3) prodn. both in vitro and in vivo. However, the p84/p110γ heterodimer is approx. 4-fold less sensitive to Gβγs than p101/p110γ. Endogenous murine p84 expression is substantially reduced in the absence of p110γ expression. We conclude that p110γ has two potential regulatory subunits in vivo, p84 and p101.

    11. 11
      Koziol-White, C. J.; Yoo, E. J.; Cao, G.; Zhang, J.; Papanikolaou, E.; Pushkarsky, I.; Andrews, A.; Himes, B. E.; Damoiseaux, R. D.; Liggett, S. B.; Di Carlo, D.; Kurten, R. C.; Panettieri, R. A. Inhibition of PI3K Promotes Dilation of Human Small Airways in a Rho Kinase-Dependent Manner. Br. J. Pharmacol. 2016, 173, 2726– 2738,  DOI: 10.1111/bph.13542
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      11
      Inhibition of PI3K promotes dilation of human small airways in a rho kinase-dependent manner
      Koziol-White, Cynthia J.; Yoo, Edwin J.; Cao, Gaoyuan; Zhang, Jie; Papanikolaou, Eleni; Pushkarsky, Ivan; Andrews, Adam; Himes, Blanca E.; Damoiseaux, Robert D.; Liggett, Stephen B.; Di Carlo, Dino; Kurten, Richard C.; Panettieri, Reynold A., Jr.
      British Journal of Pharmacology (2016), 173 (18), 2726-2738CODEN: BJPCBM; ISSN:1476-5381. (Wiley-Blackwell)
      Background and Purpose : Asthma manifests as a heterogeneous syndrome characterized by airway obstruction, inflammation and hyperresponsiveness (AHR). Although the mol. mechanisms remain unclear, activation of specific PI3K isoforms mediate inflammation and AHR. We aimed to det. whether inhibition of PI3Kδ evokes dilation of airways and to elucidate potential mechanisms. Exptl. Approach : Human precision cut lung slices from non-asthma donors and primary human airway smooth muscle (HASM) cells from both non-asthma and asthma donors were utilized. Phosphorylation of Akt, myosin phosphatase target subunit 1 (MYPT1) and myosin light chain (MLC) were assessed in HASM cells following either PI3K inhibitor or siRNA treatment. HASM relaxation was assessed by micro-pattern deformation. Reversal of constriction of airways was assessed following stimulation with PI3K or ROCK inhibitors. Key Results : Sol. inhibitors or PI3Kδ knockdown reversed carbachol-induced constriction of human airways, relaxed agonist-contracted HASM and inhibited pAkt, pMYPT1 and pMLC in HASM. Similarly, inhibition of Rho kinase also dilated human PCLS airways and suppressed pMYPT1 and pMLC. Baseline pMYPT1 was significantly elevated in HASM cells derived from asthma donors in comparison with non-asthma donors. After desensitization of the β2-adrenoceptors, a PI3Kδ inhibitor remained an effective dilator. In the presence of IL-13, dilation by a β agonist, but not PI3K inhibitor, was attenuated. Conclusion and Implications : PI3Kδ inhibitors act as dilators of human small airways. Taken together, these findings provide alternative approaches to the clin. management of airway obstruction in asthma.

    16. 16
      Collmann, E.; Bohnacker, T.; Marone, R.; Dawson, J.; Rehberg, M.; Stringer, R.; Krombach, F.; Burkhart, C.; Hirsch, E.; Hollingworth, G. J.; Thomas, M.; Wymann, M. P. Transient Targeting of Phosphoinositide 3-Kinase Acts as a Roadblock in Mast Cells’ Route to Allergy. J. Allergy Clin. Immunol. 2013, 132 (4), 959– 968,  DOI: 10.1016/j.jaci.2013.03.008
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      16
      Transient targeting of phosphoinositide 3-kinase acts as a roadblock in mast cells' route to allergy
      Collmann, Emilie; Bohnacker, Thomas; Marone, Romina; Dawson, Janet; Rehberg, Markus; Stringer, Rowan; Krombach, Fritz; Burkhart, Christoph; Hirsch, Emilio; Hollingworth, Gregory J.; Thomas, Matthew; Wymann, Matthias P.
      Journal of Allergy and Clinical Immunology (2013), 132 (4), 959-968CODEN: JACIBY; ISSN:0091-6749. (Elsevier)
      Background: Tissue mast cell nos. are dynamically regulated by recruitment of progenitors from the vasculature. It is unclear whether progenitors are recruited during allergic sensitization and whether recruitment promotes allergic responses. Objective: We sought to (1) det. the effect of mast cell recruitment on acute allergic responses and (2) to define the role of phosphoinositide 3-kinase (PI3K) isoforms in sequential steps to allergic responses. Methods: Gene-targeted mice for PI3Kγ or PI3Kδ or mice treated with isoform-specific PI3K inhibitors (a novel PI3Kγ-specific inhibitor [NVS-PI3-4] and the PI3Kδ inhibitor IC87114) were used to monitor IgE-mediated mast cell recruitment, migration, adhesion by means of intravital microscopy, degranulation, TNF-α release, and subsequent endothelial cell activation in vivo or in bone marrow-derived mast cells. Results: Functional PI3Kγ, but not PI3Kδ, was crucial for mast cell accumulation in IgE-challenged skin, TNF-α release from IgE/antigen-stimulated mast cells, and mast cell/endothelial interactions and chemotaxis. PI3Kγ-deficient bone marrow-derived mast cells did not adhere to the endothelium in TNF-α-treated cremaster muscle, whereas PI3Kδ was not required. Depletion of TNF-α blocked IgE-induced mast cell recruitment, which links tissue mast cell-derived cytokine release to endothelial activation and mast cell recruitment. Interference with mast cell recruitment protected against anaphylaxis and was superior to blockage of tissue mast cell degranulation. Conclusions: Interference with mast cell recruitment to exacerbated tissues provides a novel strategy to alleviate allergic reactions and surpassed attenuation of tissue mast cell degranulation. This results in prolonged drug action and allows for redn. of drug doses required to block anaphylaxis, an important feature for drugs targeting inflammatory disease in general.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXnslerurk%253D&md5=688f46658743dd6b6e6ca70dc5ba783b
    17. 17
      Condliffe, A. M.; Davidson, K.; Anderson, K. E.; Ellson, C. D.; Crabbe, T.; Okkenhaug, K.; Vanhaesebroeck, B.; Turner, M.; Webb, L.; Wymann, M. P.; Hirsch, E.; Ruckle, T.; Camps, M.; Rommel, C.; Jackson, S. P.; Chilvers, E. R.; Stephens, L. R.; Hawkins, P. T. Sequential Activation of Class IB and Class IA PI3K Is Important for the Primed Respiratory Burst of Human but Not Murine Neutrophils. Blood 2005, 106 (4), 1432– 1440,  DOI: 10.1182/blood-2005-03-0944
      [Crossref], Google Scholar

    18. 18
      Heit, B.; Liu, L.; Colarusso, P.; Puri, K. D.; Kubes, P. PI3K Accelerates, but Is Not Required for, Neutrophil Chemotaxis to FMLP. J. Cell Sci. 2008, 121 (Part 2), 205– 214,  DOI: 10.1242/jcs.020412
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      18
      PI3K accelerates, but is not required for, neutrophil chemotaxis to fMLP
      Heit, Bryan; Liu, Lixin; Colarusso, Pina; Puri, Kamal D.; Kubes, Paul
      Journal of Cell Science (2008), 121 (2), 205-214CODEN: JNCSAI; ISSN:0021-9533. (Company of Biologists Ltd.)
      PI3K activity, resulting in the accumulation of PIP3 along the leading edge of a chemotaxing cell, has been proposed to be an indispensable signaling event that is required for cells to undergo chemotaxis to endogenous and exogenous chemoattractants. Some studies have suggested that this might be the case for chemoattractants such as IL8, whereas chemotaxis to other stimuli, such as the bacterial peptide N-formyl-methionyl-leucyl-phenylalanine (fMLP), might occur normally in the absence of PI3K activity. Herein, the authors systematically analyze the role of PI3K in mediating chemotaxis to fMLP, both in vitro and in vivo. Using short- and long-term in vitro assays, as well as an in vivo chemotaxis assay, the authors investigated the importance of PI3K in response to the prototypic chemoattractant fMLP. Exposure of neutrophils to fMLP induced an immediate polarization, which resulted in directional migration towards fMLP within 2-3 min. PI3K-inhibited cells also polarized and migrated in a directional fashion towards fMLP; however, this process was delayed by ∼15 min, demonstrating that PI3K accelerates the initial response to fMLP, but an alternative pathway replaces PI3K over time. By contrast, p38-MAPK-inhibited cells, or cells lacking MK2, were unable to polarize in response to fMLP. Long-term chemotaxis assays using a pan-PI3K inhibitor, a PI3Kδ-specific inhibitor or PI3Kγ-knockout neutrophils, demonstrated no role for PI3K in mediating chemotaxis to fMLP, regardless of the steepness of the fMLP gradient. Similar results were obsd. in vivo, with PI3Kγ-/- cells displaying a delayed, but otherwise normal, chemotactic response to gradients of fMLP. Together, these data demonstrate that, although PI3K can enhance early responses to the bacterial chemoattractant fMLP, it is not required for migration towards this chemoattractant.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1cXitFWrsrs%253D&md5=73aa9311d863135af1b1fb6e2d1796cd
    19. 19
      Ferguson, G. J.; Milne, L.; Kulkarni, S.; Sasaki, T.; Walker, S.; Andrews, S.; Crabbe, T.; Finan, P.; Jones, G.; Jackson, S.; Camps, M.; Rommel, C.; Wymann, M.; Hirsch, E.; Hawkins, P.; Stephens, L. PI(3)Kγ Has an Important Context-Dependent Role in Neutrophil Chemokinesis. Nat. Cell Biol. 2007, 9 (1), 86– 91,  DOI: 10.1038/ncb1517
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      19
      PI(3)Kγ has an important context-dependent role in neutrophil chemokinesis
      Ferguson, G. John; Milne, Laura; Kulkarni, Suhasini; Sasaki, Takehiko; Walker, Simon; Andrews, Simon; Crabbe, Tom; Finan, Peter; Jones, Gareth; Jackson, Shaun; Camps, Montserrat; Rommel, Christian; Wymann, Matthias; Hirsch, Emilio; Hawkins, Phillip; Stephens, Len
      Nature Cell Biology (2007), 9 (1), 86-91CODEN: NCBIFN; ISSN:1465-7392. (Nature Publishing Group)
      The directional movement of cells in a gradient of external stimulus is termed chemotaxis and is important in many aspects of development and differentiated cell function. Phosphoinositide 3-kinases (PI(3)Ks) are thought to have crit. roles within the gradient-sensing machinery of a variety of highly motile cells, such as mammalian phagocytes, allowing these cells to respond quickly and efficiently to shallow gradients of sol. stimuli. Our anal. of mammalian neutrophil migration towards ligands such as fMLP shows that, although PtdIns(3,4)P2 and PtdIns(3,4,5)P3 accumulate in a PI(3)Kγ-dependent fashion at the up-gradient leading-edge, this signal is not required for efficient gradient-sensing and gradient-biased movement. PI(3)Kγ activity is however, a crit. determinant of the proportion of cells that can move, i.e., respond chemokinetically, in reaction to fMLP. Furthermore, this dependence of chemokinesis on PI(3)Kγ activity is context dependent, both with respect to the state of priming of the neutrophils and the type of surface on which they are migrating. We propose this effect of PI(3)Kγ is through roles in the regulation of some aspects of neutrophil polarization that are relevant to movement, such as integrin-based adhesion and the accumulation of polymd. (F)-actin at the leading-edge.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2sXltV2n&md5=f1eeab9aa59a08a896a5fc0c9464e0ad
    20. 20
      Mårdh, C. K.; Root, J.; Uddin, M.; Stenvall, K.; Malmgren, A.; Karabelas, K.; Thomas, M. Targets of Neutrophil Influx and Weaponry: Therapeutic Opportunities for Chronic Obstructive Airway Disease. J. Immunol. Res. 2017, 2017, 5273201,  DOI: 10.1155/2017/5273201
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      20
      Targets of Neutrophil Influx and Weaponry: Therapeutic Opportunities for Chronic Obstructive Airway Disease
      Mardh Carina Karrman; Root James; Uddin Mohib; Stenvall Kristina; Malmgren Anna; Karabelas Kostas; Thomas Matthew
      Journal of immunology research (2017), 2017 (), 5273201 ISSN:.
      Neutrophils are important effector cells of antimicrobial immunity in an acute inflammatory response, with a primary role in the clearance of extracellular pathogens. However, in respiratory diseases such as asthma and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), there is excessive infiltration and activation of neutrophils, subsequent production of reactive oxygen species, and release of serine proteases, matrix metalloproteinases, and myeloperoxidase-resulting in collateral damage as the cells infiltrate into the tissue. Increased neutrophil survival through dysregulated apoptosis facilitates continued release of neutrophil-derived mediators to perpetuate airway inflammation and tissue injury. Several target mechanisms have been investigated to address pathologic neutrophil biology and thereby provide a novel therapy for respiratory disease. These include neutrophil influx through inhibition of chemokine receptors CXCR2, CXCR1, and PI3Kγ signaling and neutrophil weaponry by protease inhibitors, targeting matrix metalloproteinases and neutrophil serine proteases. In addition, neutrophil function can be modulated using selective PI3Kδ inhibitors. This review highlights the latest advances in targeting neutrophils and their function, discusses the opportunities and risks of neutrophil inhibition, and explores how we might better develop future strategies to regulate neutrophil influx and function for respiratory diseases in dire need of novel effective therapies.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADC%252BC1cnmsFGktQ%253D%253D&md5=959897af161450bc2aa73a092cb20d0a
    21. 21
      Sapey, E.; Greenwood, H.; Walton, G.; Mann, E.; Love, A.; Aaronson, N.; Insall, R. H.; Stockley, R. A.; Lord, J. M. Phosphoinositide 3-Kinase Inhibition Restores Neutrophil Accuracy in the Elderly: Toward Targeted Treatments for Immunosenescence. Blood 2014, 123 (2), 239– 248,  DOI: 10.1182/blood-2013-08-519520
      [Crossref], Google Scholar
      There is no corresponding record for this reference.
    22. 22
      Maus, U. A.; Backi, M.; Winter, C.; Srivastava, M.; Schwarz, M. K.; Rückle, T.; Paton, J. C.; Briles, D.; Mack, M.; Welte, T.; Maus, R.; Bohle, R. M.; Seeger, W.; Rommel, C.; Hirsch, E.; Lohmeyer, J.; Preissner, K. T. Importance of Phosphoinositide 3-Kinase γ in the Host Defense against Pneumococcal Infection. Am. J. Respir. Crit. Care Med. 2007, 175 (9), 958– 966,  DOI: 10.1164/rccm.200610-1533OC
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      22
      Importance of phosphoinositide 3-kinase γ in the host defense against pneumococcal infection
      Maus, Ulrich A.; Backi, Myriam; Winter, Christine; Srivastava, Mrigank; Schwarz, Matthias K.; Rueckle, Thomas; Paton, James C.; Briles, David; Mack, Matthias; Welte, Tobias; Maus, Regina; Bohle, Rainer M.; Seeger, Werner; Rommel, Christian; Hirsch, Emilio; Lohmeyer, Juergen; Preissner, Klaus T.
      American Journal of Respiratory and Critical Care Medicine (2007), 175 (9), 958-966CODEN: AJCMED; ISSN:1073-449X. (American Thoracic Society)
      Rationale: The pivotal role of phosphoinositide 3-kinase γ (PI3Kγ) in leukocyte recruitment makes it an attractive target for immunomodulatory therapy. However, interfering with PI3Kγ signaling might increase the risk of bacterial infections in humans. Objectives: We hypothesized that deletion or pharmacol. inhibition of PI3Kγ would impair the lung inflammatory response to the prototypic gram-pos. bacterial pathogen Streptococcus pneumoniae. Methods: PI3Kγ knockout (KO) and wild-type mice were infected with S. pneumoniae or challenged with the pneumococcal virulence factor pneumolysin (PLY), and inflammatory leukocyte recruitment, bacterial pathogen elimination, and resoln./repair processes were detd. Measurements and Main Results: PI3Kγ KO mice challenged with PLY responded with lung edema and neutrophilic alveolitis, but showed a drop in alveolar macrophages and failed to recruit exudate macrophages when compared with wild-type mice. S. pneumoniae-infected PI3Kγ KO mice and wild-type mice pretreated with the pharmacol. inhibitor AS-605240 recruited similar nos. of neutrophils but substantially fewer exudate macrophages into their lungs than control animals. They also displayed a significantly reduced lung pneumococcal clearance and showed an impaired resoln./repair process, leading to progressive pneumococcal pneumonia. Conclusions: PI3Kγ gene deletion or pharmacol. inhibition of PI3Kγ leads to perturbations of crit. innate immune responses of the lung to challenge with S. pneumoniae. These data are of clin. relevance for the treatment of chronic inflammatory diseases where pharmacol. inhibition of PI3Kγ signaling to attenuate effector cell recruitment may have implications for innate immune surveillance of remote organ systems.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2sXls12ru7k%253D&md5=fc2ced3374d5191c75ff664dfa5036eb
    23. 23
      Garcia, C. C.; Tavares, L. P.; Dias, A. C. F.; Kehdy, F.; Alvarado-Arnez, L. E.; Queiroz-Junior, C. M.; Galvão, I.; Lima, B. H.; Matos, A. R.; Gonçalves, A. P. F.; Soriani, F. M.; Moraes, M. O.; Marques, J. T.; Siqueira, M. M.; Machado, A. M. V.; Sousa, L. P.; Russo, R. C.; Teixeira, M. M. Phosphatidyl Inositol 3 Kinase-Gamma Balances Antiviral and Inflammatory Responses During Influenza A H1N1 Infection: From Murine Model to Genetic Association in Patients. Front. Immunol. 2018, 9, 975,  DOI: 10.3389/fimmu.2018.00975
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      23
      Phosphatidyl inositol 3 kinase-gamma balances antiviral and inflammatory responses during influenza A H1N1 infection: from murine model to genetic association in patients
      Garcia, Cristiana C.; Tavares, Luciana P.; Dias, Ana Carolina F.; Kehdy, Fernanda; Alvarado-Arnez, Lucia Elena; Queiroz-Junior, Celso M.; Galvao, Izabela; Lima, Braulio H.; Matos, Aline R.; Goncalves, Ana Paula F.; Soriani, Frederico M.; Moraes, Milton O.; Marques, Joao T.; Siqueira, Marilda M.; Machado, Alexandre M. V.; Sousa, Lirlandia P.; Russo, Remo C.; Teixeira, Mauro M.
      Frontiers in Immunology (2018), 9 (), 975/1-975/18CODEN: FIRMCW; ISSN:1664-3224. (Frontiers Media S.A.)
      Influenza A virus (IAV) infection causes severe pulmonary disease characterized by intense leukocyte infiltration. Phosphoinositide-3 kinases (PI3Ks) are central signaling enzymes, involved in cell growth, survival, and migration. Class IB PI3K or phosphatidyl inositol 3 kinase-gamma (PI3K γ), mainly expressed by leukocytes, is involved in cell migration during inflammation. Here, we investigated the contribution of PI3K γ for the inflammatory and antiviral responses to IAV. PI3K γ knockout (KO) mice were highly susceptible to lethality following infection with influenza A/WSN/33 H1N1. In the early time points of infection, infiltration of neutrophils was higher than WT mice whereas type-I and type-III IFN expression and p38 activation were reduced in PI3K γ KO mice resulting in higher viral loads when compared with WT mice. Blockade of p38 in WT macrophages infected with IAV reduced levels of interferon-stimulated gene 15 protein to those induced in PI3K γ KO macrophages, suggesting that p38 is downstream of antiviral responses mediated by PI3K γ. PI3K γ KO-derived fibroblasts or macrophages showed reduced type-I IFN transcription and altered pro-inflammatory cytokines suggesting a cell autonomous imbalance between inflammatory and antiviral responses. Seven days after IAV infection, there were reduced infiltration of natural killer cells and CD8+ T lymphocytes, increased concn. of inflammatory cytokines in bronchoalveolar fluid, reduced nos. of resolving macrophages, and IL-10 levels in PI3K γ KO. This imbalanced environment in PI3K γ KO-infected mice culminated in enhanced lung neutrophil infiltration, reactive oxygen species release, and lung damage that together with the increased viral loads, contributed to higher mortality in PI3K γ KO mice compared with WT mice. In humans, we tested the genetic assocn. of disease severity in influenza A/H1N1pdm09-infected patients with three potentially functional PIK3CG single-nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs), rs1129293, rs17847825, and rs2230460. We obsd. that SNPs rs17847825 and rs2230460 (A and T alleles, resp.) were significantly assocd. with protection from severe disease using the recessive model in patients infected with influenza A(H1N1)pdm09. Altogether, our results suggest that PI3K γ is crucial in balancing antiviral and inflammatory responses to IAV infection.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXit1Cqu7rO&md5=a6539381a1e742799fa711785cc10eac
    24. 24
      Zelenetz, A. D.; Barrientos, J. C.; Brown, J. R.; Coiffier, B.; Delgado, J.; Egyed, M.; Ghia, P.; Illés, Á.; Jurczak, W.; Marlton, P.; Montillo, M.; Morschhauser, F.; Pristupa, A. S.; Robak, T.; Sharman, J. P.; Simpson, D.; Smolej, L.; Tausch, E.; Adewoye, A. H.; Dreiling, L. K.; Kim, Y.; Stilgenbauer, S.; Hillmen, P. Idelalisib or Placebo in Combination with Bendamustine and Rituximab in Patients with Relapsed or Refractory Chronic Lymphocytic Leukaemia: Interim Results from a Phase 3, Randomised, Double-Blind, Placebo-Controlled Trial. Lancet Oncol. 2017, 18 (3), 297– 311,  DOI: 10.1016/S1470-2045(16)30671-4
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      24
      Idelalisib or placebo in combination with bendamustine and rituximab in patients with relapsed or refractory chronic lymphocytic leukaemia: interim results from a phase 3, randomised, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial
      Zelenetz, Andrew D.; Barrientos, Jacqueline C.; Brown, Jennifer R.; Coiffier, Bertrand; Delgado, Julio; Egyed, Miklos; Ghia, Paolo; Illes, Arpad; Jurczak, Wojciech; Marlton, Paula; Montillo, Marco; Morschhauser, Franck; Pristupa, Alexander S.; Robak, Tadeusz; Sharman, Jeff P.; Simpson, David; Smolej, Lukas; Tausch, Eugen; Adewoye, Adeboye H.; Dreiling, Lyndah K.; Kim, Yeonhee; Stilgenbauer, Stephan; Hillmen, Peter
      Lancet Oncology (2017), 18 (3), 297-311CODEN: LOANBN; ISSN:1470-2045. (Elsevier Ltd.)
      Bendamustine plus rituximab is a std. of care for the management of patients with relapsed or refractory chronic lymphocytic leukemia. New therapies are needed to improve clin. relevant outcomes in these patients. We assessed the efficacy and safety of adding idelalisib, a first-in-class targeted phosphoinositide-3-kinase δ inhibitor, to bendamustine plus rituximab in this population. For this international, multicentre, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial, adult patients (≥18 years) with relapsed or refractory chronic lymphocytic leukemia requiring treatment who had measurable lymphadenopathy by CT or MRI and disease progression within 36 mo since their last previous therapy were enrolled. Patients were randomly assigned (1:1) by a central interactive web response system to receive bendamustine plus rituximab for a max. of six cycles (bendamustine: 70 mg/m2 i.v. on days 1 and 2 for six 28-day cycles; rituximab: 375 mg/m2 on day 1 of cycle 1, and 500 mg/m2 on day 1 of cycles 2-6) in addn. to either twice-daily oral idelalisib (150 mg) or placebo until disease progression or intolerable study drug-related toxicity. Randomisation was stratified by high-risk features (IGHV, del[17p], or TP53 mutation) and refractory vs. relapsed disease. The primary endpoint was progression-free survival assessed by an independent review committee in the intention-to-treat population. This trial is ongoing and is registered with ClinicalTrials.gov, no. NCT01569295. Between June 26, 2012, and Aug 21, 2014, 416 patients were enrolled and randomly assigned to the idelalisib (n=207) and placebo (n=209) groups. At a median follow-up of 14 mo (IQR 7-18), median progression-free survival was 20·8 mo (95% CI 16·6-26·4) in the idelalisib group and 11·1 mo (8·9-11·1) in the placebo group (hazard ratio [HR] 0·33, 95% CI 0·25-0·44; p<0·0001). The most frequent grade 3 or worse adverse events in the idelalisib group were neutropenia (124 [60%] of 207 patients) and febrile neutropenia (48 [23%]), whereas in the placebo group they were neutropenia (99 [47%] of 209) and thrombocytopenia (27 [13%]). An increased risk of infection was reported in the idelalisib group compared with the placebo group (grade ≥3 infections and infestations: 80 [39%] of 207 vs 52 [25%] of 209). Serious adverse events, including febrile neutropenia, pneumonia, and pyrexia, were more common in the idelalisib group (140 [68%] of 207 patients) than in the placebo group (92 [44%] of 209). Treatment-emergent adverse events leading to death occurred in 23 (11%) patients in the idelalisib group and 15 (7%) in the placebo group, including six deaths from infections in the idelalisib group and three from infections in the placebo group. Idelalisib in combination with bendamustine plus rituximab improved progression-free survival compared with bendamustine plus rituximab alone in patients with relapsed or refractory chronic lymphocytic leukemia. However, careful attention needs to be paid to management of serious adverse events and infections assocd. with this regimen during treatment selection.Gilead Sciences Inc.

      44
      A multicentre, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, crossover study to investigate the efficacy, safety, tolerability, and pharmacokinetics of repeat doses of inhaled nemiralisib in adults with persistent, uncontrolled asthma
      Khindri, Sanjeev; Cahn, Anthony; Begg, Malcolm; Montembault, Mickael; Leemereise, Claudia; Cui, Yi; Hogg, Annabel; Wajdner, Hannah; Yang, Shuying; Robertson, Jon; Hamblin, J. Nicole; Ludwig-Sengpiel, Andrea; Kornmann, Oliver; Hessel, Edith M.
      Journal of Pharmacology and Experimental Therapeutics (2018), 367 (3), 405-413CODEN: JPETAB; ISSN:1521-0103. (American Society for Pharmacology and Experimental Therapeutics)
      Phosphoinositide 3-kinase δ (PI3Kδ) is a lipid kinase involved in leukocyte recruitment and activation. Activation of PI3Kδ has been linked to airway inflammation and asthma pathogenesis. This randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, crossover study investigated the efficacy, safety, tolerability, and pharmacokinetics of a PI3Kδ inhibitor, nemiralisib (GSK2269557), in patients with persistent, uncontrolled asthma. Patients (n = 50) received once-daily inhaled nemiralisib (1000 μg) or placebo for 28 days, with a crossover to the alternative treatment following a 4-wk washout period. Spirometry demonstrated no discernible difference in trough forced expiratory vol. in 1 s (FEV1) from baseline (adjusted posterior median 7 mL; 95% credible interval -83, 102 mL) between nemiralisib and placebo treatment at day 28 (primary endpoint). These results were supported by most secondary endpoints, including weighted mean FEV1 (0-4 h) and change in trough forced vital capacity at day 28. Nemiralisib was generally well-tolerated, with few side effects except for post-inhalation cough (nemiralisib: 35%; placebo: 9%). At day 14, sputum interleukin (IL)-5, IL-13, IL-6, and IL-8 levels were reduced by a median of 17%, 7%, 15%, and 8%, resp., when comparing nemiralisib with placebo [n = 15 (IL-5, IL-8) or 16 (IL-6, IL-13); posterior probability of a true ratio. >0%: 78%, 64%, 76%, and 63%, resp.]. These results suggest that nemiralisib inhibited PI3Kδ locally; however, this did not translate into meaningful clin. improvement. Further studies will investigate the potential efficacy of nemiralisib in patients with asthma with other specific more severe phenotypes, including those who are colonized with bacteria and frequently exacerbate.

      Yoo, E. J.; Ojiaku, C. A.; Sunder, K.; Panettieri, R. A. Phosphoinositide 3-Kinase in Asthma: Novel Roles and Therapeutic Approaches. Am. J. Respir. Cell Mol. Biol. 2017, 56 (6), 700– 707,  DOI: 10.1165/rcmb.2016-0308TR
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      59
      Phosphoinositide 3-kinase in asthma: novel roles and therapeutic approaches
      Yoo, Edwin J.; Ojiaku, Christie A.; Sunder, Krishna; Panettieri, Reynold A., Jr.
      American Journal of Respiratory Cell and Molecular Biology (2017), 56 (6), 700-707CODEN: AJRBEL; ISSN:1044-1549. (American Thoracic Society)
      Asthma manifests as airway hyperresponsiveness and inflammation, including coughing, wheezing, and shortness of breath. Immune cells and airway structural cells orchestrate asthma pathophysiol., leading to mucus secretion, airway narrowing, and obstruction. Phosphoinositide 3-kinase, a lipid kinase, plays a crucial role in many of the cellular and mol. mechanisms driving asthma pathophysiol. and represents an attractive therapeutic target. Here, we summarize the diverse roles of phosphoinositide 3-kinase in the pathogenesis of asthma and discuss novel therapeutic approaches to treatment.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2sXht1artrrI&md5=67d7e791406eae6be3ebb2a352a13e9d

      Nair, K. S.; Cheson, B. The Role of Idelalisib in the Treatment of Relapsed and Refractory Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia. Ther. Adv. Hematol. 2016, 7 (2), 69– 84,  DOI: 10.1177/2040620715625966
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      69
      The role of idelalisib in the treatment of relapsed and refractory chronic lymphocytic leukemia
      Nair, Kruti Sheth; Cheson, Bruce
      Therapeutic Advances in Hematology (2016), 7 (2), 69-84CODEN: TAHHAT; ISSN:2040-6207. (Sage Publications Ltd.)
      Idelalisib is a first in class, delta isoform specific, PI3-kinase inhibitor. Based on its high level of efficacy and acceptable safety profile, this oral drug has been approved by the US Food and Drug Administration as a single agent for the treatment of relapsed or refractory small lymphocytic lymphoma, and follicular non-Hodgkin lymphoma, and in combination with rituximab for patients with chronic lymphocytic leukemia. Adverse effects of particular concern include diarrhea, pneumonitis, and transient elevations of hepatic transaminase levels. Efforts to improve on the activity of this drug have included combinations with std. chemotherapy agents, such as bendamustine, and other targeted therapies, including checkpoint inhibitors. However, other combinations have been assocd. with life-threatening and fatal toxicities. Thus, the development of such regimens should be conducted carefully in the context of a clin. research study. Idelalisib has a vital role as second-line therapy for chronic lymphocytic leukemia, esp. for patients with high-risk disease and multiple comorbidities, and studies are exploring the use of this agent as front-line therapy to improve the outcome of patients with indolent B-cell malignancies.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2sXmvVWgsr8%253D&md5=295f67243254ea3ff1df0327c6bbedc1

    73. 73
      Burris, H. A.; Flinn, I. W.; Patel, M. R.; Fenske, T. S.; Deng, C.; Brander, D. M.; Gutierrez, M.; Essell, J. H.; Kuhn, J. G.; Miskin, H. P.; Sportelli, P.; Weiss, M. S.; Vakkalanka, S.; Savona, M. R.; O’Connor, O. A. Umbralisib, a Novel PI3Kδ and Casein Kinase-1ε Inhibitor, in Relapsed or Refractory Chronic Lymphocytic Leukaemia and Lymphoma: An Open-Label, Phase 1, Dose-Escalation, First-in-Human Study. Lancet Oncol. 2018, 19 (4), 486– 496,  DOI: 10.1016/S1470-2045(18)30082-2
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      73
      Umbralisib, a novel PI3Kδ and casein kinase-1ε inhibitor, in relapsed or refractory chronic lymphocytic leukaemia and lymphoma: an open-label, phase 1, dose-escalation, first-in-human study
      Burris, Howard A., III; Flinn, Ian W.; Patel, Manish R.; Fenske, Timothy S.; Deng, Changchun; Brander, Danielle M.; Gutierrez, Martin; Essell, James H.; Kuhn, John G.; Miskin, Hari P.; Sportelli, Peter; Weiss, Michael S.; Vakkalanka, Swaroop; Savona, Michael R.; O'Connor, Owen A.
      Lancet Oncology (2018), 19 (4), 486-496CODEN: LOANBN; ISSN:1470-2045. (Elsevier Ltd.)
      Umbralisib (TGR-1202) is a novel next-generation inhibitor of phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase (PI3K) isoform p110δ (PI3Kδ), which is structurally distinct from other PI3Kδ inhibitors and shows improved isoform selectivity. Umbralisib also uniquely inhibits casein kinase-1ε, a major regulator of protein translation. The aim of this first-in-human phase 1 study was to establish the safety and preliminary activity profile of umbralisib in patients with haematol. malignancies. We did an open-label, phase 1, dose-escalation study at seven clinics in the USA. We recruited patients aged at least 18 years with relapsed or refractory chronic lymphocytic leukemia or small lymphocytic lymphoma, B-cell and T-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma, or Hodgkin's lymphoma, who had received one or more previous lines of therapy, with measurable and assessable disease, and adequate organ system function. Patients self-administered an umbralisib oral tablet once per day in 28-day cycles, with dose escalation done in a traditional 3 + 3 design to establish safety and det. the max. tolerated dose. In initial cohorts, patients took umbralisib in a fasting state at a starting dose of 50 mg, increasing to 100, 200, 400, 800, 1200, and 1800 mg until the max. tolerated dose was reached, or the maximal dose cohort was accrued without a dose-limiting toxicity. Subsequent cohorts self-administered a micronized formulation of umbralisib tablet in a fed state at an initial dose of 200 mg, increased in increments to 400, 800, 1200, and 1800 mg until the max. tolerated dose or the maximal dose level was accrued. In August, 2014, all patients still on study were transitioned to 800 mg of the micronized formulation and dosing of the initial formulation was discontinued. The primary endpoints of the study were investigator-assessed safety in all treated patients (the safety population), the max. tolerated dose, and the pharmacokinetics of umbralisib. Secondary endpoints included preliminary assessments of anti-cancer activity (objective responses and duration of response). Follow-up stopped for a patient once they discontinued therapy. This study has been completed and is registered with ClinicalTrials.gov, no. NCT01767766. Between Jan 17, 2013, and Jan 14, 2016, we enrolled and treated 90 patients with umbralisib. The median duration of treatment and follow-up was 4·7 cycles (IQR 2·0-14·0) or 133 days (IQR 55-335). The most common treatment-emergent adverse events irresp. of causality were diarrhea (in 39 [43%] of 90 patients), nausea (38 [42%]), and fatigue (28 [31%]). The most common grade 3 or 4 adverse events were neutropenia (in 12 [13%] patients), anemia (eight [9%]) and thrombocytopenia (six [7%]). Serious adverse events considered at least possibly related to umbralisib occurred in seven patients: pneumonia in three (3%) patients, lung infection in one (1%), febrile neutropenia in one (1%), and colitis in two (2%), one of whom also had febrile neutropenia. The max. tolerated dose was 1200 mg of the micronized formulation, with 800 mg of this formulation selected as the recommended phase 2 dose. Both cases of colitis occurred at above the recommended phase 2 dose. 33 (37%) of the 90 patients enrolled had an objective response to treatment with umbralisib. Umbralisib was well tolerated and showed preliminary signs of activity in patients with relapsed or refractory haematol. malignancies. The safety profile of umbralisib in this phase 1 study was distinct from that of other PI3Kδ inhibitors, with fewer occurrences of autoimmune-like toxicities such as colitis. These findings warrant further evaluation of this agent in this setting.TG Therapeutics.

    81. 81
      Coutre, S. E.; Barrientos, J. C.; Brown, J. R.; de Vos, S.; Furman, R. R.; Keating, M. J.; Li, D.; O’Brien, S. M.; Pagel, J. M.; Poleski, M. H.; Sharman, J. P.; Yao, N.-S.; Zelenetz, A. D.       81
      Management of adverse events associated with idelalisib treatment: expert panel opinion
      Coutre, Steven E.; Barrientos, Jacqueline C.; Brown, Jennifer R.; de Vos, Sven; Furman, Richard R.; Keating, Michael J.; Li, Daniel; O'Brien, Susan M.; Pagel, John M.; Poleski, Martin H.; Sharman, Jeff P.; Yao, Nai-Shun; Zelenetz, Andrew D.
      Leukemia & Lymphoma (2015), 56 (10), 2779-2786CODEN: LELYEA; ISSN:1029-2403. (Taylor & Francis Ltd.)
      Idelalisib is a first-in-class selective, oral, phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase delta (PI3Kδ) inhibitor approved for the treatment of several types of blood cancer. Idelalisib has demonstrated significant efficacy and a tolerable safety profile in clin. trials. However, the US prescribing information contains a black box warning for fatal and/or severe diarrhea or colitis, hepatotoxicity, pneumonitis and intestinal perforation. An expert panel was convened to review the pathol. of these treatment-emergent adverse events (TEAEs) to propose key management tools for patients receiving idelalisib therapy. This article provides an overview of idelalisib TEAEs reported in clin. trials, and a summary of the panel's recommendations for identification and management of idelalisib treatment-emergent diarrhea or colitis as well as a discussion of transaminitis and pneumonitis. For idelalisib-related diarrhea or colitis (including unresolved grade 2 and grade ≥ 3), after exclusion of infectious causes, the panel recommends individualized treatment with budesonide or oral or i.v. steroid therapy.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXhvFKju73O&md5=649cb8c3d6fe0a60f74b3f9413e4706a
